DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX NEWS HOST: I can tighten or loosen your car just based on air pressure.

BRIAN KILMEADE, FOX NEWS HOST: Right.

MCDOWELL: Just so in case--

JUAN WILLIAMS, FOX NEWS HOST: All right. Maybe you should marry her.

KILMEADE: Juan.

WILLIAMS: That's it for us. You know what, we're going to be back here on Monday. And we want to see you with us. Have a great weekend everyone.

KILMEADE: He won't be chewing gum.

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS HOST: Hurricane Dorian pounds the Carolina Outer Banks as the death toll climbs in what is left of the Bahamas. The August jobs report and optimism over China trade talks fueled President Trump celebration of the U.S. economy. And true or false. Trying to tell reality from fantasy as big tech goes after deep fakes. This is Special Report.

Good evening. Welcome to Washington. I'm Bret Baier. The death toll could be staggering. That from a Bahamian official just getting a sense of the magnitude of the devastation left by Hurricane Dorian in the Bahamas. We're getting new information tonight on that devastation. A warning, the images and descriptions in this next report are tough to watch and hear.

The official death toll has risen to 30 with thousands of homes destroyed. But the unofficial death toll could skyrocket from there. When you actually get to see the worst hit areas like Abaco Island. Correspondent Steve Harrigan is there tonight. Steve.

STEVE HARRIGAN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Bret, I am standing here on Abaco Islands in the Bahamas and what was someone's house just a week ago, in what was someone's neighborhood also just a week ago. This was no ordinary storm that tore the roof off of a few houses. This was 185 mile per hour winds over and over again for 36 plus hours. The whole scene here as far as you can see to the left, to the right is like a place that's been jumbled like a snow globe. That's been shook.

Things are just crushed down to the foundation. We've seen people wander through here and try and find items of value. It's even hard for some people to locate where their house was. That's how jumbled this landscape is. But there is little of value to find.

We've heard quite a bit about the death toll. And I can tell you from standing here that death toll is going to continue to rise dramatically in the days ahead. No one knows how many dead bodies are still in the wreckage out here. This was a church where some people tried to find shelter from the storm instead it collapsed killing many. We're not going to show you but from where I'm standing, I can see at least one two dead bodies bloated and rotting in the sun.

We have seen some signs of hope though especially from Bahamians volunteering with their own boats to try and help people get off of this island.

This is an all-volunteer flotilla. You have people from different parts of the Bahamas arriving on their own private boats. They're bringing supplies, food and water and then they're taking people off of Abaco Islands, people who are desperate to leave. People have lost everything. People have been waiting around the clock here at the water's edge hoping to get their families off this island. These boats will eventually go to Nassau people leaving everything they had behind to get on these boats to save their families.

A real danger now is for people who are too frail, too poor, too weak to move. A lot of people in the makeshift hospital here are running out of medications.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: There's people that just look hopeless and just you know just need to find hope somewhere somehow nothing the government hasn't come through; they haven't said nothing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HARRIGAN: There has been heroic efforts by U.S. Coast Guard pilots and cutters to rescue people from the air, from the sea and it's estimated that those efforts will be stepped up in the coming days. This is a tough place to get to, but just looking around with dead bodies still protruding from this wreckage, you really get a sense that not much is really being done now for the people of the Bahamas by anyone. Bret.

BAIER: Steve Harrigan. Steve, thank you. Steve and Chris Pontius, the photographer have seen a lot of war and a lot of disaster in their time and this devastation as you heard unlike most.

Now to the U.S. East Coast, several hundred people may be trapped on one island of North Carolina's Outer Banks tonight. Correspondent Doug McKelway is on the North Carolina coast.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DOUG MCKELWAY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: The flag at Frying Pan light station was still flying today frayed but defiant. It was Dorian though that got one last punch in on the Tar Heel State overnight.

As hope grew, the coastal regions would be spared the worst. Dorian made its first U.S. landfall on the Outer Banks, hardest hit Ocracoke Island, accessible only by sea and air.

Some residents were reportedly forced into their attics to escape a huge storm surge.

MIKE SPRAYBERRY, NORTH CAROLINA EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT: We have heard unofficially that there could be hundreds of people that are trapped out there, we don't have a really good number on it.

MCKELWAY: At 2:30 this afternoon, Hyde County officials sent word that air transportation units were being sent to Ocracoke to evacuate the stranded with priority for the sick and elderly. But most of the Carolinas fared better.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, it did, and it discarded us. So that's a good thing.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: How does everybody feel about that.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Oh wonderful. Believe me. It's a good thing.

MCKELWAY: Dorian's eye wall kept a steady path just off the coast meeting most residents felt only its weaker northerly winds west of the eye wall. Those north winds dissipated the tornado threat and also pushed potential flood waters of Wilmington's Cape Fear River southward into the open ocean sparing the city from serious flooding.

Three hurricanes in three years has given valued experience to first responders and those who restore electricity.

JEFF BROOKS, DUKE ENERGY: We've upgraded a lot of poles and wires especially near coastal regions putting in stronger poles so those tools helping our linemen.

MCKELWAY: One Duke Energy official texted Fox News today "we're restoring power so fast, I can't keep up with our crews."

As the storm moved northward prompting new warnings for states up the East Coast into Canada, residents of Topsail BeachNorth Carolina were breathing a collective sigh of relief.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: You prepare for the worst. Pray for the best and be thankful.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCKELWAY: And as you look live down the beach here at Surf City at North Carolina, you'll see scores and scores of new staircases coming down the sand dunes. They're new because the old ones were washed away along with the sand dunes during Hurricane Florence. Exactly, a year ago today. Nobody wanted to see a repeat of that last night. Bret.

BAIER: Doug McKelway live in Surf City. Doug, thanks. President Trump is getting some backup tonight from an unexpected source. The Chairman of the Federal Reserve who the President harshly criticized in recent weeks says he is not expecting a recession in the U.S. or globally. That reinforces what the President has been saying despite the forecasts of some economists.

The news comes on a day filled with economic headlines. Chief White House Correspondent John Roberts runs through them tonight for us.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: The monthly jobs report came in well below expectations, 130,000 jobs created versus 158,000 projected. Still, President Trump put a positive spin on the numbers tweeting, the economy is great. The only thing adding to uncertainty is the fake news.

The report would have been worse had the federal government not hired 25,000 people to conduct next year's census. The private sector created only 96,000 jobs, the lowest number since February. The retail sector lost 11,000 jobs as did the transportation sector.

While unemployment stayed steady at 3.7 percent. Wages grew and more people joined the labor force. Democrats slammed the report in a statement. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi saying, the August jobs report offers little comfort in an economy faltering under the Trump administration's reckless agenda to undermine the health, financial security and well-being of the American people.

The President's Chief Economic Adviser described the report as solid, not spectacular, but Larry Kudlow still found a way to sew a silk purse from the numbers zeroing in on the so-called household survey which found 590,000 more people working in August than in July.

LARRY KUDLOW, NATIONAL ECONOMIC COUNCIL DIRECTOR: America is working. America is getting paid well. America is spending and saving and producing. So, I think this is a dynamite report.

ROBERTS: Analysts saw the jobs report as a sign the economy is slowing. But speaking in Switzerland today, Fed Chairman Jay Powell insisted the U.S. economy is still strong.

JAY POWELL, FEDERAL RESERVE CHAIRMAN: The United States economy has continued to perform well and is in is in a good place. The most likely outlook for our economy remains a favorable one.

ROBERTS: President Trump today kept up the heat on his Fed Chairman again urging him to cut rates in a tweet saying, where did I find this guy Jerome. Oh well you can't win them all.

The promise of more trade talks with China kept the markets marching forward today. But Powell warning the trade war is having an impact saying the Fed stands ready to add more stimulus to the economy.

POWELL: I think it is the case that uncertainty around trade policy is causing some companies to hold back now on investment and so, our obligation is to use our tools to support the economy and that's what we'll continue to do.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ROBERTS: Powell also said today that despite trade uncertainties and signs that the global economy is slowing down, he does not see the U.S. economy slipping into a recession. Donald Trump still does not appear to be a fan of the Fed Chairman. Bret.

BAIER: John Roberts live in the North Lawn. John, thank you. Stocks were mixed today. The Dow gained 69. The S&P 500 was up 3. The NASDAQ lost 14. For the week, the Dow was up 1.5 percentage points. The S&P and the NASDAQ gained one and three quarters.

The Trump administration is going after California's authority to set its own automobile gas mileage standards. The administration wants to end the 50 year old practice of giving California its own rules and institute a nationwide standard.

As Correspondent Gillian Turner tells us tonight, California will not go down without a fight.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GILLIAN TURNER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: President Trump has his sights set on rolling back fuel emission standards set by President Obama. More than seven years ago.

Behind the scenes, the White House has been working with government regulators for weeks on new rules for automakers. They plan to roll out any day now.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We want to make it good for the consumer. In California, they have a standard where the cars are going to have to be much more expensive and won't be as good.

TURNER: Unhappy about the threat of rollbacks, the state of California recently struck a deal with several major automakers. The state says it's better for the environment and its customers.

Volkswagen, Honda, BMW and Ford have all pledged to stick to the 2012 Obama requirement to double the fuel economy of new cars and light duty trucks by 2025.

But today the EPA and Transportation Departments officially put California and the four automakers on notice. In a letter they write this framework agreement appears to be inconsistent with federal law. President Trump's acting budget director agrees saying California is trying to impose its failed policies on the rest of the country by making new cars significantly more expensive and less safe.

According to automakers the Justice Department has opened an anti-trust probe that experts warn could become a lawsuit.

MYRON EBELL, COMPETITIVE ENTERPRISE INSTITUTE: The Trump administration has tried to restore the rule of law and take away the ability of California to set fuel economy standards for the entire country.

TURNER: California lawmakers say the Trump proposal guts pollution standards set by President Obama in 2012. The biggest single U.S. policy to reduce planet warming carbon dioxide emissions.

Senator Feinstein saying, I expect the administration's effort like so many other bad ideas will be taken to court and overturned.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TURNER: Ford and Honda both say they'll cooperate with the Justice Department's probe. The major car companies have been lobbying President Trump since his first week in office. Now it seems at least some of them are changing their tune. Bret.

BAIER: Gillian, thank you. Tonight, federal health officials are urging people to stop vaping until they figure out why some users are coming down with serious breathing illnesses. Officials say they've identified 450 possible cases in 33 states. At least three people have died so far. They said no single vaping device liquid or ingredient has been tied to all of the illnesses.

Many of the sickened, but not all were people who say they had been vaping THC, the chemical that gives marijuana it's high.

The U.S. Navy has relieved three senior leaders of the elite SEAL team seven from their positions. The action follows a decision by the military to bring home a SEAL platoon from Iraq. Fox News reports the platoon members refused to cooperate with investigation into an alleged sexual assault involving unit personnel. There are also allegations of drinking while deployed.

This is shaping up to be a crucial weekend in Hong Kong. Thousands of protesters are confronting police there as they demand pro-democracy reforms from the Chinese territory. Police are responding with force. Chief Correspondent Jonathan Hunt is in Hong Kong again tonight.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JONATHAN HUNT, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: It may be a taste of things to come this weekend. Protesters and police clashing once again Friday night outside a Hong Kong subway station with riot police heavily outnumbered at times firing tear gas and rubber bullets.

Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam tried this week to draw the sting from the summer long protests by scrapping a much despised extradition Bill. But that appears to have done little to allay the fears of many protesters that the Chinese government is seeking to take tighter control of Hong Kong and break the central promise it made when the territory was handed over by the British in 1997.

Anson Chan was Hong Kong's Chief Secretary at the time.

ANSON CHAN, FORMER HONG KONG CHIEF SECRETARY: In minds of many people in Hong Kong, one country two systems at the moment is one country, one and a half system. And if this erosion continues and very soon it will become one country, one system.

HUNT: The 14 weeks of street protests have done real damage to Hong Kong's economy with spending plummeting this summer according to the city's Retail Management Association and its tourism board.

Carrie Lam's political supporters say the time has come to stop the economic bleeding.

BERNARD CHAN, HONG KONG EXECUTIVE COUNCIL: Once we can get back to a dialogue and bring people back to some calmness though hopefully. I think people will come back. Investor will come back. Visitor will come back. So, I'm quite hopeful.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HUNT: That hope that optimism seems likely to be sorely tested this weekend as protesters plan once again to draw international attention to their calls by trying to shut down Hong Kong's airport, the eighth busiest in the world. Bret.

BAIER: Jonathan Hunt live in Hong Kong early Saturday morning. Jonathan, thank you. Up next, big tech under fire tonight from state governments and deep fake producers. We'll look at the very real challenges ahead.

First, here's what some of our Fox affiliates around the country are covering tonight. FOX 2 in San Francisco where a criminal case dealing with the deaths of 36 people trapped in a fire inside a San Francisco Bay Area warehouse nearly three years ago will stretch on. A jury has acquitted one defendant and deadlocked on the other.

WSVN in Miami, as an American Airlines' mechanic is accused of sabotaging a flight over stalled union contract negotiations. Court documents say Abdul Majid Alani admitted during an interview he tampered with the navigation system on the plane so that he could collect overtime work. As the pilots powered up that plane at Miami International Airport, they saw an error message for a system that tracks speed, nose direction and other critical flight information and they aborted that takeoff.

And this is a live look at rainy Denver from FOX 31. You can barely make it out. The big story there tonight the state of Colorado asked the Environmental Protection Agency to downgrade the air quality rating of the state's biggest population center. The EPA will consider whether to lower the ozone status of Denver and eight other Northern Colorado counties from moderate to serious that would force the state to work harder to reduce harmful pollution, but also bring tougher and costly regulations for businesses.

That is tonight's live look outside the Beltway from Special Report. We'll be right back.

BAIER: The Trump administration is moving to toughen sanctions against Cuba by reducing the amount of money Cuban-Americans can send to family members on the island. The Treasury Department will limit remittances to 1000 dollars per person per quarter. The new rules also no longer allow transfers of money to non-family members.

We are going to tell you about two big challenges for Big Tech tonight. One involves a group of state attorneys general going after Google and Facebook. The other is an effort to combat a technology that can produce images of people saying and doing things they have never said or done. Chief Intelligence correspondent Catherine Herridge is here tonight with details. Good evening, Catherine.

CATHERINE HERRIDGE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Thank you, Bret, and good evening. The deep big challenge is designed to produce technology that can be used by everyone to better detect when artificial intelligence is used to manipulate video by swapping out a face or a mouth to mislead viewers about the content.

During a recent hearing, lawmakers saw how images can be easily altered. The initiative which includes FacebookMicrosoft as well as academics from major tech institutions is part of a broad effort to combat misinformation campaigns in advance of the 2020 election. This week a senior FBI official said the Bureau learned "hard lessons from 2016." He recognized the need to get ahead of disinformation campaigns as well as closing the gap between government and social media firms.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PAUL ABBATE, FBI ASSOCIATE DEPUTY DIRECTOR: We're pushing information intelligence out to the companies to help them spot bad actors on their platforms and remove them. And they're giving information back to us to inform our efforts, so we can aggressively go out and take action against them and cut them off at the knees.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HERRIDGE: The technology is moving so quickly that face swapping videos may soon be eclipsed by deep fake audio which experts say can be made from just 20 minutes of recordings. This summer a leading cybersecurity expert warned of a handful of artificial intelligence cyber-attacks that used voice swapping to impersonate chief executives. Their recordings were used to trick employees into making large wire transfers.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JEFF GREENE, SYMANTEC: Idea that someone is going to spoof the voice of your CEO or your boss or the president or whoever. It's pretty frightening and unfortunately, it's not that complicated.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HERRIDGE: Separately today New York's attorney general announced that eight states both Republican and Democrat as well as the District of Columbia had begun antitrust investigations of Facebook. State regulators are also expected to target Google and make that announcement next week. Bret.

BAIER: Catherine, thank you.

HERRIDGE: You're welcome.

BAIER: Up next, the first in the nation primary state finally get some love from most of the Democratic presidential contenders.

First, beyond our borders tonight. Afghanistan's President has postponed a planned visit to Washington early next week where he was to discuss the U.S. Taliban peace talks. That's according to The Associated Press. The decision comes as the Taliban claimed responsibility for a third attack in the provincial capital in Afghanistan in less than a week.

Events were held in Brazil and abroad Thursday to show support to the Amazon rainforest experiencing an increase this year in the number of fires. In Rio de Janeiro dozens of activists met under the rain in the city center wearing T-shirts. Some of them saying fight for the Amazon. Official data says fires in Brazil are up 59 percent this year.

And former Zimbabwe leader Robert Mugabe has died in Singapore at the age of 95. The former guerrilla chief took power after independence from white minority rule in 1980, enjoyed strong support among the population and even the West. Soon after taking over as prime minister, but he was reviled in later years as the economy collapsed. And human rights violations increased exponentially. Just some of the other stories beyond our borders tonight. We'll be right back.

BAIER: America's election headquarters tonight, New Hampshire is the center of the Democrat's political universe tonight. Most of the top presidential candidates' contenders are there as they prepare for the state party's convention tomorrow. This evening Correspondent Peter Doocy shows us how the frontrunner is taking on the president and the competition.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PETER DOOCY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Amid questions about why he wants to be President.

JOE BIDEN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I'd like to come here and not run.

DOOCY: Joe Biden continues to make his campaign all about President Trump who he is trying to apply pressure on following a weaker than expected jobs report.

BIDEN: And we're teetering on a recession. He's becoming more erratic. He inherited a pretty good economy from Barack Obama just like he inherited everything in his life.

DOOCY: One independent candidate who could have dealt a blow to Biden's bid is bowing out. Former Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz tells supporters "if I went forward, there is a risk that my name would appear on ballots even if a moderate Democrat wins the nomination. And that is not a risk I am willing to take."

Since Biden is not a self-funding billionaire like Schultz, he's funding his campaign the old fashioned way with checks from wealthy donors. Although one of last night's fundraisers raised questions about whether or not Biden was breaking a promise not to accept money from fossil fuel executives.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Andrew Goldman, the guy who is one of the co-sponsors of the fundraiser hit a company called - he was co-founder of a company called Western LNG. He currently doesn't have day-to-day responsibilities.

BIDEN: What I was told by my staff is that he did not have any responsibility relating to the company.

DOOCY: Biden considered canceling but showed up. He insisted last night he won't take a dime from the fossil fuel industry. And he insisted today he won't take a dime of dark money either.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Please, a clear answer. What are you going to do about dark money in politics in 500 words or less?

(APPLAUSE)

JOE BIDEN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Number one, take none of it.

DOOCY: New Hampshire Democrats seem eager to move forward, and they seem to have already moved past the Biden's campaign's early controversies.

BIDEN: I want to be clear what was said.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: -- to give me a hug.

BIDEN: I have permission to give her a hug. That's the greatest honor I've had today.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

DOOCY: Joe Biden was one of the only people here in New Hampshire tonight on a chilly evening not wearing a jacket. You can see nobody from his staff has given him a jacket yet. And he joked a lot about how he was feeling cold before being eventually confronted by an activist about global warming. Biden went over to shook the young woman's hand. He told her to look into his eyes. And then promised to eliminate all fossil fuels in this country within the next 30 years. Bret?

BAIER: If you want to turn around and ask him a question or two, we'll hang on.

DOOCY: Do you have a question, Bret?

BAIER: Come on SPECIAL REPORT.

DOOCY: We can try for that if you want to stay here.

BAIER: We'll let you work that for a little bit. He looks like he's busy. Peter, thank you.

After a week of setbacks for British Prime Minister Boris Johnson, another one today as he tries to pull the United Kingdom out of the European Union. Lawmakers are refusing to support Johnson's call for a new election until he secures a deal to delay the withdrawal. Senior foreign affairs correspondent Amy Kellogg has the latest tonight from London.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: As many of that opinion will say "content."

CROWD: Content.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The contrary not content. The contents have it.

AMY KELLOGG, FOX NEWS SENIOR FOREIGN AFFAIRS CORRESPONDENT: The last parliamentary hurdle to legislation blocking withdrawal from the E.U. with no deal in place by the end of October. It's due to become law Monday. Prime minister Boris Johnson remains dead set against begging Brussels for more time, and Monday will call yet again for a brand-new election next month. But the opposition as of today is not budging to his demand. They worry Johnson will find a way to thwart them and they will end with a no deal Brexit.

LIZ SAVILLE ROBERTS, WELSH NATIONALIST PARTY: Boris Johnson is on the run. He's going to start behaving very soon like a rat in a trap.

KELLOGG: But Johnson, for the second day at events looking like a candidate, this time in Scotland with fishermen and farmers, has thrown this right back at the opposition.

BORIS JOHNSON, BRITISH PRIME MINISTER: I think it's the most sensational paradox. Never in history has there been an opposition party that has been given the chance to have an election and has turned it down.

KELLOGG: But the electioneering hasn't gone unnoticed. The prime minister was chastised by a police chief for using officers as a, quote, "backdrop" for a speech yesterday that was supposed to be focused on police recruitment.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

KELLOGG: Johnson and his girlfriend will be spending the night with the queen. Prime ministers traditionally pay her a September visit in her castle in Balmoral, Scotland, but this visit will no doubt be one like no other. Bret?

BAIER: We'll follow it all. Amy Kellogg live in London. Amy, thank you.

Job gains, China trade talks, and the president going after California. We'll talk about all the economic news with the panel when we come back.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY KUDLOW, NATIONAL ECONOMIC COUNCIL DIRECTOR: The 130,000 payrolls is a solid number. It's not a spectacular number. I'm just going to say this. America is working. America is getting paid well. America is spending and saving and producing. So I think this is a dynamite report.

JEROME POWELL, FEDERAL RESERVE CHAIRMAN: The Fed has through the course of the year seen fit to lower the expected path of interest rates. That has supported the economy. That's one of the reasons why the outlook is still a favorable one despite these crosswinds they've been facing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Some good news from the Fed chair who has not been receiving the best tweets from the White House and from the president. Meantime, the August jobs report, you heard the descriptions, 130,000 jobs added, lower than economists had predicted. Unemployment rate unchanged in 3.7. That is remaining near a 50-year low, not in these numbers though. Unemployment for African-Americans fell sharply to 5.5 percent in August, hitting its lowest level since recordkeeping began in 1972. Some of that for not seeking jobs or out of the job market, also low unemployment rate for Hispanic or Latino ethnicity. The president mentions that on the trail quite a bit.

The Dow rocky road today, but it also enjoyed for some time the uptick. And the real question, though, for the week, it is up, but what is going to happen with the Fed going forward? And that's what the market watches very closely.

Let's bring in our panel to talk about the economy, Byron York, chief political correspondent for the "Washington Examiner," Charles Lane, opinion writer for "The Washington Post," and Jason Riley, "Wall Street Journal" columnist and senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute. Jason, as you look at this jobs report, the situation right now, what do you see?

JASON RILEY, "WALL STREET JOURNAL" COLUMNIST: It's a mixed bag. I like Larry Kudlow as much as the next guy, but it is a mixed bag. It's not all good news. The employment numbers are strong, wages are growing faster than inflation, but the unemployment rate is a lagging indicator. Something has already changed in the economy, and we know that from other trends that we see. Manufacturing is shrinking for the first time since President Trump was elected. That is a bad sign. Businesses are buying less equipment. Business investment has gone down. And you talk to CEOs, you talk to business leaders, and they cite this trade war. They say it has introduced uncertainty, and now we've got more tariffs coming along that are going to hit earbuds and flat screen televisions and shoes. I think something like 70 percent of shoes in the country are made in China. So people are worried about these global trends, and I think we need to look at this jobs report in that context.

BAIER: And as you look at the economic changes since the president took office, we put this up often and it changes from time to time, you can see the real GDP growth is ground. But unemployment also down, consumer confidence up as is the average hourly earnings.

The Fed chair, though, today, Chuck, with some kind of comforting news, even though he didn't really lay the cards out about how the rates changes are going to happen down the road, for those saying that a recession was on the way, he squelched that.

CHARLES LANE, OPINION WRITER, "WASHINGTON POST": And he has actually been saying consistently for some time the Fed does not see a recession coming. The report that just came out to me sort of is a stay the course report for the Fed because it wasn't super on jobs, which suggests that they are going to provide another perhaps 25 basis days rate cut, which was priced into the market, so the market was OK with this report.

I really think that in addition to all the other uncertainty Jason is talking about, another factor is -- we can laugh about them, but these tweets against the Fed that the president keeps putting out. Powell has this delicate roll as any Fed chairman does to stick the statutory mandate of price stability at maximum employment politically independent from the electoral branches of the government. And the more he is under fire from the president, the harder it is for him to maintain the appearance of impartiality.

BAIER: We've showed on the panel before that this president is not unique in going after the Fed chairman. He just does it on Twitter, that is unique, because he uses Twitter as his printing press to get out the word.

BRYON YORK, CHIEF POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT, "WASHINGTON EXAMINER": He does. I don't want to go the full Kudlow here, but there are some good things in this report, and I think it's important to look at it. For example, wages are doing quite well. Workforce participation improving. I think the important thing to do is to look at this in the context of all this rather irresponsible talk we have had about a recession lately. In some media circles there was an almost unseemly anticipation of a recession being right around the corner. And it's clearly not the case, and it's not just the Fed chairman who is saying this. It would be amazing the president should say thank you. Thank you, Chairman Powell, that would just blow everybody's mind. But lots of people now are saying it's just not going to happen in this imminent future.

BAIER: Meantime, there's an effort to change emission standards. The EPA Transportation Department saying to California the framework of this agreement that you're trying to do, essentially make your own standards, appears to be inconsistent with federal law, and it goes on to say that essentially they want to come up with their own deal.

RILEY: The automakers are complaining about regulatory uncertainty, but I would take that with a grain of salt. The real uncertainty here is the mandate, the government mandates to build cars that people don't want to buy, namely electric cars. And that is causing the uncertainty, and you are getting more expensive cars that people do want to buy with their prices up because carmakers have to, because of the government mandate, make these electric cars that don't sell as well, and they make up their money with profits on cars that people do buy.

So what I think we do need to do, and what I think the administration is doing here is trying to get rid of some of these regulations so that the automakers can simply meet consumer demand.

BAIER: So California is pushing back, saying they are going to fight it.

LANE: Of course they are going to fight it. They've fought President Trump on everything else. But it was interesting because people were wondering how is President Trump going to fight back on this aggressive move by California, sort of cut its own separate deal with these automakers. And his answer was, OK, I will see you and raise you one. I'm going to strip you of this waiver, of this unique authority that you enjoy, and of course we'll see how that plays out in the courts.

I take it the administration acted because they want to try to get this done before the first term ends and while he's sure who the Supreme Court is going to be. I do think that we are reaching this point in this country where we are compiling a lot of social objectives into the price of an automobile. There is the environmental side, but there's also the president's own objectives on trade. If USMCA goes up, the ITC, the International Trade Commission predicts it will add to the cost of a car. If there were tariffs on Europe which he's threatened about, it might be nice if you'd just leave that all to the market, but that's not how we do things.

BAIER: I'm going to start with you in the Lightning Round. Next up, Lightning Round, end of sharpie-gate week, yes, Winners and Losers, plus Candidate Casino.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, (R) PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: That was the original chart. It was going toward the Gulf. That was what was originally projected.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It looks like it was drawn with a sharpie.

TRUMP: I don't know. I don't know. I don't know.

ANNE GEARAN, "WASHINGTON POST": One White House official told my colleagues there is no one else who could have marked it up that way. There's only one suspect.

REP. JAMIE RASKIN, (D-MD): This is "Saturday Night Live" style cartoonish behavior by the president of the United States.

CHRIS CHRISTIE, FORMER NEW JERSEY GOVERNOR: The fight never ends. And so the president feels like he's under siege constantly, so he's never going to stop fighting.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: And those are the facts.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Sharpie-gate coming to an end because it's Friday. And we have "The Washington Post" saying it in fact was the president, citing multiple sources. You have NOAA out with a statement late today that says "From Wednesday, August 28th, through Monday, September 2nd, the information provided by NOAA and the National Hurricane Center to President Trump and the wider public demonstrated that tropical force winds from Hurricane Dorian could impact Alabama." It goes on to say that the Birmingham National Weather Services Sunday morning tweet spoke in absolute terms that were inconsistent with probabilities from the best forecast products available at the time.

In the meantime, you have the Trump campaign tweeting out an offer for supporters to buy a pen, saying "Buy the official Trump marker which is different than very other marker on the market because this one has the special ability to drive CNN and the rest of the fake news crazy. Keep Markers Great."

There's where we are. It's Friday. We're back with the panel. Quickly, sharpie-gate.

BRYON YORK, CHIEF POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT, "WASHINGTON EXAMINER": They're already making money selling plastic straws. This is the dumbest story since the last dumb story we had. The president was right for a little while, then he was wrong to push this. The press made a huge deal of it, and now the president, he may be talking about this for weeks now. I don't know. It astonishes me that he goes day after day after day showing these things.

BAIER: Chuck?

LANE: I thought he was crazy to pursue this. I think Chris Christie has his fingers on it. It's just like the crowd at the inauguration. He raised a huge fuss about that even though it seemed wrong. On the other hand, I wouldn't be surprised in the parts of the country where he's very popular this helps him because people see him as embattled unfairly by the media.

BAIER: I talked to someone the other day who said that President Trump is the Rain Man of trolling the press. In other words, sometimes he backs into it, but then he is there and he trolls to great success.

RILEY: He's right, and we've known that for a while. We've learned nothing new here. We've learned Trump won't back down from a fight. And we've learned that there is no controversy that is too petty or stupid for the press to harp on if it paints this president in a bad light.

BAIER: We are going to take a walk down Candidate Casino. It's Friday. Candidate Casino, the Democratic primary, you have $100 in chips, you have to bet. Where is your bat?

YORK: OK, I put $35 on Elizabeth Warren. I put $30 on Kamala Harris. I am a little bit bearish on Biden, I put $25 on him. And because we are supposed to make things interesting, I put $5 on Michelle Obama, just for the heck of it. And the rest of the field, tells you how much I think they're going to win.

BAIER: A new table, a new felt, the whole thing. Go ahead, Chuck.

LANE: This is my first visit to the casino, I'm not really familiar with the house rules. But I put $40 to the frontrunner Joe Biden because I'm a conventional thinker, Elizabeth Warren, Bernie Sanders, and so on. I split $20 between Kamala Harris and Pete Buttigieg, and I'm hedging my bets with a moderate to be determined if Biden falters, $5.

RILEY: I have Biden leading and Warren and Sanders close behind. I think Biden is a real leader, but I think he's ahead because Warren and Sanders are splitting that progressive vote. And if one of them backs the other, Biden's lead could disappear very quickly.

BAIER: How lightning can we be? Winner and Losers, let's go.

YORK: Amy Klobuchar is the winner who despite have 0.9 percent of the vote in the Real Clear Politics average of polls made it into next week's debate. The loser, Bill de Blasio. We found out that he spent just seven hours at city hall during the entire month. He declared for the president. The question for New Yorkers is, is that a good thing or a bad thing?

BAIER: That was a little rolling thunder. More lightning.

LANE: It gives me no joy to declare the Taliban my winner of the week because they are about to get away with murder literally and negotiate a very favorable deal for U.S. troop withdrawal in Afghanistan.

My loser, no surprise I think, Boris Johnson. He may win this fight for Brexit and the prime ministership in the end, but he lost a series of embarrassing votes in Parliament this week, and his own brother quit his party.

ROBERTS: My winners are the millions of protestors in Hong Kong who just won't back down. My loser is the CNN town hall on climate change which was not only too long, Bret, but was really more about trying to scare people than it was about trying to enlighten them on what's really a complex issue. That was a real disservice to their viewers.

BAIER: It was not lightning. But you were, Jason, so you're my winner.

(LAUGHTER)

BAIER: Thank you, panel. When we come back, "Notable Quotables."

BAIER: Finally tonight, it is Friday. That means "Notable Quotables."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: There may be a point in time during this storm where if you call 911, they won't be able to get to you.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I just pray that we can come out of this.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I mean the thousands of bodies out here, man, there's trailers with bodies. Bodies are all around.

DONALD TRUMP, (R) PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: A category five is something I don't know that I've ever even heard the term.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm tired of the dying for the people of the state of Texas.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, this is -- up.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I saw myself as a coach. I wanted to be out on the playing field where the lads are going toe the toe with the enemy.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The weirdest thing about the electoral college is the fact that if it wasn't specifically in the Constitution for the presidency, it would be unconstitutional.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Do not encourage people to print out list, because the next list that comes out, your name will be on it.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: There's only one chlorinated chicken that I can see in this house, and he's on that bench.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Order.

TRUMP: Boris is a friend of mine, and he's going at it.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Behave yourself! Be a good boy, young man.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Are you going nuts?

(LAUGHTER)

JOE BIDEN, (D) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Look, the reason I came onto "The Jimmy Kimmel show" is because I'm not.

(LAUGHTER)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Somebody doctored this map, folks.

TRUMP: I don't know, I don't know.

But that was the original chart.

(MUSIC)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: That is one week in Washington. You know when you add an "order" it makes everything better. Makes everything better.

Thanks for inviting us into your home tonight. This weekend, watch "FOX News Sunday" for a live interview with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. You can check your local listing for times. That is it for this "Special Report." It's been a long week, but it's been fair, balanced, and unafraid.

"The Story" hosted by Martha MacCallum starts right now. And Martha, the NFL started last night, so the Patriots, will they make it this year?

MARTHA MACCALLUM, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Oh, absolutely.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: ... no collusion. Was he talking about the 28 million ballots?

SARAH SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: I'd have to go back and check and look at that. I didn't see that. I'm sorry.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Sarah?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The price tag on the Russia investigation? And if so, that's highly inflated.

SANDERS: Again, I'd have to check, Jeff, I'm not sure of that.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: ... testify or not. If you could just talk about this ...

SANDERS: That's a question I will refer you to outside counsel. Davis?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The President is going to Pennsylvania tomorrow, what does he plan to say and what's the (inaudible) this year's 9/11 (inaudible)?

SANDERS: Certainly, the focus will be ...

HALA GORANI, HOST, HALA GORANI TONIGHT: Sarah Sanders there in the briefing room at the White House, saying that no lie detectors are being talked about as a possibility now to try find to figure out who wrote that anonymous op-ed in the "New York Times." She also criticized Bob Woodward who wrote of course that book using sources there that were unnamed to describe the situation in the White House that is being described as chaotic among other things. That's going to do it for "Hala Gorani Tonight." "Quest Means Business" is coming up next.

RICHARD QUEST, HOST, QUEST MEANS BUSINESS: It's an hour until the closing bell on Wall Street. The last chance to make your trade. The Dow, the good gains of the day have evaporated. The good news is the losses are small. Look at the break apart of the Dow. You have the Nike at the top, you have Boeing towards the bottom. We'll explain why, because let me show you, the market drivers of the day.

CBS is down, Les Moonves is out, the #MeToo Movement hits the C-suite. Alibaba and Snap lose key executives, all changed, but tech. And Nike, I showed you the shares near the top of the Dow, it's controversial campaign is getting real market results. Live from the world's financial capital on a rainy day in New York City. It's Monday, it's the 10th of September. I'm Richard Quest. I mean business.

Good evening at a new earlier time, but the same quality program. It's a pivotal moment for the #MeToo Movement and for CBS. The Chief Executive Les Moonves is leaving the company immediately, pushed out by fresh accusations of sexual assault. Moonves is the first Fortune 500 CEO to be ousted through the #MeToo era. The controversy isn't over because the details of Moonves' payout is still to be decided. CBS shares have regained some of the early losses. They are still down for the day, that's partly because with Moonves gone, the battle for control of CBS has come to an end. Our media correspondent Brian Stelter is following it all.

BRIAN STELTER, MEDIA CORRESPONDENT, CNN: Hello.

QUEST: You've worked in the media business throughout all your professional career, explain.

STELTER: There's never been an earthquake like this. It is as simple as that. We've talked about a lot of #MeToo figures, a lot of men who have lost their jobs in the past year, but nothing like this, nothing like the Fortune 500 CEO, who vowed to fight on and stayed in the role for six weeks, but was eventually forced out this time yesterday.

QUEST: Before we talk about the CBS side of the equation. When Weinstein happened and all the #MeToo happened, did Moonves know that - that did you think that he had this entire smoldering volcano waiting to erupt within ...

STELTER: You just asked me the most interesting question of this story. I believe he did know. I believe he did know he was vulnerable to this and that makes me wonder something else, did he go picking a fight inside his company on purpose? Did he go trying to fight with his controlling shareholder, trying to wrest away control of CBS on purpose, to create another story line? Because, really, we have seen the merger of two story lines here, this tug of war, which he lost to Shari Redstone over the future of CBS, and this #MeToo case.

I wonder if ever the actor, ever the Hollywood star, Moonves went out and tried to make his own story, but no matter what, it ended badly for him.

QUEST: Okay, let's talk about CBS. They've put $120 million into a guarantor trust, he would have gotten $140 million, $20 million will go to charities or to organizations. But I mean, how does CBS justify not suspending him and then firing him or reinstating if the allegations are true? Why allow him to resign?

STELTER: I think the answer is that you're talking about a board of directors that was mostly made of up of Moonves' old friends, his pals. He was essentially running this board. It was mostly elderly, mostly white- man board. That has changed as of Sunday, now there's been a shakeup of the board, but I think a lot of this had to do with Moonves surrounded by his friends, believing he could get through this.

Eventually, then the law firms came in. Eventually more women came forward. Eventually these negotiations of Redstone continued to progress and it became in the words of one source, untenable for Moonves to continue.

[15:05:12]

STELTER: But even now, as you said, $120 million still possibly on the table, incredible development.

QUEST: Okay, on that, let's just look at the national amusements - what's the agreement? What is the - have they agreed to do?

STELTER: Everybody agrees to put down the weapons. Everybody has surrendered.

QUEST: So what happens?

STELTER: So now CBS, Redstone tightens her control on the company. This is the Redstone family. Sumner Redstone of course, the owner for a couple of a decades, now her daughter - Shari - is in charge. Now, going forward, there's talk about a possible CBS-Viacom recombination.

However, I think what's more likely is we're going to see better merge for CBS and this board has reaffirmed the - the phones are open, the lines are open, call with your offers. I would be surprise if a year or two from now, CBS is not in the hands of either some big tech company or some other big buyer.

QUEST: Extraordinary developments. Good to see you. Thank you, sir. Good to see you always.

STELTER: Thanks.

QUEST: We're going to continue talking about it. Les Moonves may be gone, the question shareholders and activists want the answer to is how much he should take with him? As I was just describing, it depends on the outcome of the investigation into his alleged misconduct. Now, the full payout would be $140 million, of which $20 million would go to organizations to support the #MeToo Movement and Equality for Women in the Workplace.

But as we just said, $120 million is in trust. It would only return to CBS if the board decides that Moonves could be fired for cause. Ronan Farrow who led the investigative journalism and wrote the original report and the update just over the weekend tell CNN it was the idea that Moonves would get anything at all that prompted more women to come forward.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RONAN FARROW, CONTRIBUTING WRITER, THE NEW YORK TIMES: One of the most important things about this story is, this is the first Fortune 500 CEO to step down for these reasons in the #MeToo era. This is someone who was supposed to be immune to criticism, that many of these are women stayed quiet about for years because they thought he had complete impunity.

So, yes, the reluctance of this Board to act and he has a lot of these women, that's troubling. It shows how far we still have to go. But also, this is a story of how far we have come because no one thought we would be here.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

QUEST: Joining me in the C-Suite is Davia Tamin, media reputation strategist. The C-Suite is appropriate for us to talk about these events. Your study and your research shows the number of CEOs or the number of people accused on what's happened to them.

DAVIA TAMIN, MEDIA REPUTATION STRATEGIST: As of today, it's 700, so Les Moonves makes 700.

QUEST: Seven hundred people accused?

TAMIN: High profile people accused since Weinstein.

QUEST: Right, and what happened to most of them?

TAMIN: Well, most of them have - there was no most. So, a certain percentage, about half have left. About half still remain or they're continuing to be under investigation. So it's not clear. I think the amount of time that it takes between investigation and final resolution is shortening now from what it was a year ago.

QUEST: The idea that Les Moonves could walk out the door with more than $100 million, what would you say?

TAMIN: You know, I don't find that the worst thing in the world. I think that he lived a life - I'm not supporting him by any stretch of the imagination, don't get me wrong. KJOS: I want to -- I want to give the Argentineans the possibility to fly on these and fast, and have a good flight and learn maybe to fly longer maybe with us to Europe.

QUEST: But what do you want to do with Norwegian? What do you see as its - - because everywhere you look now, you're being nipped after the heels, the legacy, the level has come along, Euro wings is now going long, you're smiling again. Euro wings is going longer, France is coming along with you and all the others.

KJOS: There will always be others.

QUEST: There will always be others. But they're attacking you on all sides.

KJOS: Not actually, they are -- some routes, but all this have competitors, it's just about two that you have. At the end, we got up to scale and we certainly served so many citizens in U.S. and we have a huge network in Europe.

So we are at the level now, we should definitely release our harvesting now.

QUEST: And what will it take though to become profitable?

KJOS: Well, we ramped up the long haul this year tremendously, no, they are -- they're all on the peak now, we can -- no, we can start harvesting. So we should -- our future as I see it will be bright.

QUEST: But it is important for you, I mean you're arguably -- Jeff Bezos of Amazon has spent the entire history of the company until now taking losses to build for market share and to build the corner stone that we've got. At some point, you're going to have to make money while your investors and shareholders are going to say, this is not worth -- just in the low.

KJOS: But then again, out of 17 years we have made money for 15 years, and I wouldn't have gone into this I didn't think I would -- it would be profitable.

QUEST: Brexit, finally on Brexit. Now, you're going to tell me that you'll be fine because of your different subsidiaries. You're going to tell me that you've got the U.K. subsidiary which will handle all the U.K. stuff, and the Irish subsidiary will handle -- and anyway, Norway is part of the European common area for aviation.

But you must still be worried.

KJOS: Well, actually, we are fit(ph) to the task(ph), the only thing I don't understand is what are they going to do with all the bilateral agreements that you used to have, they have to refix(ph) it. So it's a huge amount of work they have to go through, but they can do it, I mean, it's --

QUEST: No, let's take for example your U.K. routes to the U.S. London Gatwick is crucial to you --

KJOS: Yes, it is --

QUEST: It's your largest base --

KJOS: Yes, that's right --

QUEST: London Gatwick is crucial to you, the U.S., U.K. flights will have to be renegotiated. I'm confident that, yes, that the British and the Americans will fix it because they need open sky, everybody needs opened sky, everybody needs the passengers and the two-ways(ph) to really take the world, that is the most -- well, actually, today, 20 percent of all jobs, job creation comes from this industry.

[15:55:00] You would -- nobody would want to stop that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

QUEST: Five minutes before the close of trade in New York, the -- this is the scenario, this is the way things look. In Europe, the markets were all higher, even the FTSE managed to eat out a very small gain. The encouragement came from the EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier who claims the Brexit deal could happen by November.

The -- no, got 2.3 percent. The reason for that very simply, the government now seemingly will respect the EU budget rules or at least it seems less, and the scenario being it's less likely that there will be a full blown showdown between the new populist government in Rome and the -- and with Brussels.

But it's still early days, that's just one day, and that is just Monday. As to the New York market, a good start to the morning and then it drifted off and then it completely evaporated into the afternoon, and this is really -- this is your trade talks, this is your worries, this is your earnings and all eyes on the things on what is likely to be for the future.

Very small losses though considering the sort of day, trading is just about finished, we'll have a profitable moment after the break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

QUEST: Tonight's profitable moment, "Cbs", the board of directors effectively put their fingers on the thumb on the scale when they decided to let Les Moonves resign, put the money, 120 million into a guarantor's trust and only after the investigation decide whether he should get that money or not, will be fired without a penny.

By doing it that way, they have effectively already tilted the decision towards him getting something. Perhaps arguably a far better way would have been to have suspended him, pending the investigation with no money put in any form of trust, and then decide whether he goes with the full amount minus whatever or whether he's allowed to resign because the allegations don't stand up or he gets fired without a penny.

At the moment, it would be very difficult for them to do that. But the board needs to remember, the world is watching what happens at "Cbs". And that's QUEST MEANS BUSINESS for tonight, I am Richard Quest in New York. Whatever you're up to in the hours ahead, I hope it's profitable.

The closing bell on Wall Street --

(BELL RINGING)

Trading is over.

END

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: ... no collusion. Was he talking about the 28 million ballots?

SARAH SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: I'd have to go back and check and look at that. I didn't see that. I'm sorry.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Sarah?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The price tag on the Russia investigation? And if so, that's highly inflated.

SANDERS: Again, I'd have to check, Jeff, I'm not sure of that.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: ... testify or not. If you could just talk about this ...

SANDERS: That's a question I will refer you to outside counsel. Davis?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The President is going to Pennsylvania tomorrow, what does he plan to say and what's the (inaudible) this year's 9/11 (inaudible)?

SANDERS: Certainly, the focus will be ...

HALA GORANI, HOST, HALA GORANI TONIGHT: Sarah Sanders there in the briefing room at the White House, saying that no lie detectors are being talked about as a possibility now to try find to figure out who wrote that anonymous op-ed in the "New York Times." She also criticized Bob Woodward who wrote of course that book using sources there that were unnamed to describe the situation in the White House that is being described as chaotic among other things. That's going to do it for "Hala Gorani Tonight." "Quest Means Business" is coming up next.

RICHARD QUEST, HOST, QUEST MEANS BUSINESS: It's an hour until the closing bell on Wall Street. The last chance to make your trade. The Dow, the good gains of the day have evaporated. The good news is the losses are small. Look at the break apart of the Dow. You have the Nike at the top, you have Boeing towards the bottom. We'll explain why, because let me show you, the market drivers of the day.

CBS is down, Les Moonves is out, the #MeToo Movement hits the C-suite. Alibaba and Snap lose key executives, all changed, but tech. And Nike, I showed you the shares near the top of the Dow, it's controversial campaign is getting real market results. Live from the world's financial capital on a rainy day in New York City. It's Monday, it's the 10th of September. I'm Richard Quest. I mean business.

Good evening at a new earlier time, but the same quality program. It's a pivotal moment for the #MeToo Movement and for CBS. The Chief Executive Les Moonves is leaving the company immediately, pushed out by fresh accusations of sexual assault. Moonves is the first Fortune 500 CEO to be ousted through the #MeToo era. The controversy isn't over because the details of Moonves' payout is still to be decided. CBS shares have regained some of the early losses. They are still down for the day, that's partly because with Moonves gone, the battle for control of CBS has come to an end. Our media correspondent Brian Stelter is following it all.

BRIAN STELTER, MEDIA CORRESPONDENT, CNN: Hello.

QUEST: You've worked in the media business throughout all your professional career, explain.

STELTER: There's never been an earthquake like this. It is as simple as that. We've talked about a lot of #MeToo figures, a lot of men who have lost their jobs in the past year, but nothing like this, nothing like the Fortune 500 CEO, who vowed to fight on and stayed in the role for six weeks, but was eventually forced out this time yesterday.

QUEST: Before we talk about the CBS side of the equation. When Weinstein happened and all the #MeToo happened, did Moonves know that - that did you think that he had this entire smoldering volcano waiting to erupt within ...

STELTER: You just asked me the most interesting question of this story. I believe he did know. I believe he did know he was vulnerable to this and that makes me wonder something else, did he go picking a fight inside his company on purpose? Did he go trying to fight with his controlling shareholder, trying to wrest away control of CBS on purpose, to create another story line? Because, really, we have seen the merger of two story lines here, this tug of war, which he lost to Shari Redstone over the future of CBS, and this #MeToo case.

I wonder if ever the actor, ever the Hollywood star, Moonves went out and tried to make his own story, but no matter what, it ended badly for him.

QUEST: Okay, let's talk about CBS. They've put $120 million into a guarantor trust, he would have gotten $140 million, $20 million will go to charities or to organizations. But I mean, how does CBS justify not suspending him and then firing him or reinstating if the allegations are true? Why allow him to resign?

STELTER: I think the answer is that you're talking about a board of directors that was mostly made of up of Moonves' old friends, his pals. He was essentially running this board. It was mostly elderly, mostly white- man board. That has changed as of Sunday, now there's been a shakeup of the board, but I think a lot of this had to do with Moonves surrounded by his friends, believing he could get through this.

Eventually, then the law firms came in. Eventually more women came forward. Eventually these negotiations of Redstone continued to progress and it became in the words of one source, untenable for Moonves to continue.

[15:05:12]

STELTER: But even now, as you said, $120 million still possibly on the table, incredible development.

QUEST: Okay, on that, let's just look at the national amusements - what's the agreement? What is the - have they agreed to do?

STELTER: Everybody agrees to put down the weapons. Everybody has surrendered.

QUEST: So what happens?

STELTER: So now CBS, Redstone tightens her control on the company. This is the Redstone family. Sumner Redstone of course, the owner for a couple of a decades, now her daughter - Shari - is in charge. Now, going forward, there's talk about a possible CBS-Viacom recombination.

However, I think what's more likely is we're going to see better merge for CBS and this board has reaffirmed the - the phones are open, the lines are open, call with your offers. I would be surprise if a year or two from now, CBS is not in the hands of either some big tech company or some other big buyer.

QUEST: Extraordinary developments. Good to see you. Thank you, sir. Good to see you always.

STELTER: Thanks.

QUEST: We're going to continue talking about it. Les Moonves may be gone, the question shareholders and activists want the answer to is how much he should take with him? As I was just describing, it depends on the outcome of the investigation into his alleged misconduct. Now, the full payout would be $140 million, of which $20 million would go to organizations to support the #MeToo Movement and Equality for Women in the Workplace.

But as we just said, $120 million is in trust. It would only return to CBS if the board decides that Moonves could be fired for cause. Ronan Farrow who led the investigative journalism and wrote the original report and the update just over the weekend tell CNN it was the idea that Moonves would get anything at all that prompted more women to come forward.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RONAN FARROW, CONTRIBUTING WRITER, THE NEW YORK TIMES: One of the most important things about this story is, this is the first Fortune 500 CEO to step down for these reasons in the #MeToo era. This is someone who was supposed to be immune to criticism, that many of these are women stayed quiet about for years because they thought he had complete impunity.

So, yes, the reluctance of this Board to act and he has a lot of these women, that's troubling. It shows how far we still have to go. But also, this is a story of how far we have come because no one thought we would be here.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

QUEST: Joining me in the C-Suite is Davia Tamin, media reputation strategist. The C-Suite is appropriate for us to talk about these events. Your study and your research shows the number of CEOs or the number of people accused on what's happened to them.

DAVIA TAMIN, MEDIA REPUTATION STRATEGIST: As of today, it's 700, so Les Moonves makes 700.

QUEST: Seven hundred people accused?

TAMIN: High profile people accused since Weinstein.

QUEST: Right, and what happened to most of them?

TAMIN: Well, most of them have - there was no most. So, a certain percentage, about half have left. About half still remain or they're continuing to be under investigation. So it's not clear. I think the amount of time that it takes between investigation and final resolution is shortening now from what it was a year ago.

QUEST: The idea that Les Moonves could walk out the door with more than $100 million, what would you say?

TAMIN: You know, I don't find that the worst thing in the world. I think that he lived a life - I'm not supporting him by any stretch of the imagination, don't get me wrong. But he lived according to some rules, those rules changed somewhere about a year ago, about two years ago now. And I am most concerned that he is caught and that he sets a precedent now that others who do this are caught. It's a game change and it's a culture change.

QUEST: I agree, and if it was a normal job, and we're talking about $100,000.00 which for a top executive is not a fortune, that would be fine, but we're talking about $100 million. We're talking about life-changing events. All right, he's earned similar amounts. He's earned $20 million to $30 million for the last 20 years, he's not short of the price of a cup of tea. But it's symbolic.

TAMIN: It's symbolic and it's probably - if they find that there is an investigation that there's real merit to all of this, then it should be.

QUEST: What does it say then that he's been allowed to resign pending an investigation where the up side is vast and the Board is probably in his favor?

TAMIN: Well, he's been allowed, he's been made to resign, right? So he hasn't been allowed to resign.

QUEST: I'll resign for $100 million.

TAMIN: I would, too, tomorrow. But I think that ht e point is, he has - he has lost all the reputational equity that he ever had. So whatever he walks away with, he's lost it all.

QUEST: Let's talk on that front. The #MeToo Movement, at some point, there will be - when I say cut off, I don't mean a cut off in terms - because bad behavior, appalling activities, must always - should always be held to account. But at some stage, people will say, "Okay, he did this, but he shouldn't be fired."

[15:10:13]

TAMIN: Yes, you know what ...

QUEST: Are not there yet?

TAMIN: No, we are not there yet.

QUEST: And what about Moonves?

TAMIN: No, no. I know. We're not there yet for anyone. We are way far away from that. We are so much at the tip of this iceberg. There is so much underneath the surface at this point, that there is a long way to go. And I think Boards know that, I think corporate Boards know that. I think that's why they're so fixed on looking at culture now and toxic culture and all the other stuff because they know what the viability is.

QUEST: What do you think - and this is a sort of a no win question ...

TAMIN: All right.

QUEST: ... for you. What do you think the right way for a Board - I mean, at what point is dismissal the answer for events happening 30 years ago in a different culture?

TAMIN: That's a hard one. It really is a hard one, but I think that when they come to light that you have to work on the facts that you get and I think dismissal is appropriate.

QUEST: Let's talk about Serena, let's listen to what she had to say at the Open, after she was fined. She lost and was fined.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SERENA WILLIAMS, PROFESIONAL TENNIS PLAYER: I'm here fighting for women's rights and for women's equality and for all kinds of stuff and for me to say, thief and for him to take a game, it made me feel like it was a sexist remark. I mean, like, he's never took a game from a man because they said thief. For me, it blows my mind.

The fact that I have to go through this is just an example for the next person that has emotions and that want to express themselves and they want to be a strong woman and they're going to be allowed to go that because of today, maybe it didn't work out for me, but it's going to work out for the next person.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

QUEST: Are you with her on that?

TAMIN: I think that rules have to be equal and I think that responses have to be equal and I think that's more unconscious bias is what I think, but I think that the rules haven't been and they won't be for a long time, but you have to call out what you think is biased, and she's doing it.

QUEST: And it's really maybe not for us to say whether it was or wasn't. I mean, calling the umpire thief is pretty serious stuff in a competition of a sport or ...

TAMIN: Well, have others, though, called him thief before? That is the question, right? It's got to be equally applied and it hasn't been for so long, we don't even know what that looks like anymore.

QUEST: Exactly.

TAMIN: Right? So we're finding out though because we're finding out by testing the limits.

QUEST: Great that you came in to help us test them. Please come back again.

TAMIN: Thank you.

QUEST: Thank you. A look at the markets. The Dow is struggling to go green, the S&P and NASDAQ set to snap a four-day streak and tech shares bouncing back from a rough week.

Actually, you know, I do need to keep reminding myself, and new perhaps, that we are in - I look at those numbers, and I'm so used to it being after the closing bell. but it's not. We are in the last hour of trade, where the final decisions are made on how the day should end. And to learn the Dow may be off just a couple of tootling points today. There will be moments where you will truly see the reason and wisdom of why we have come to you an hour earlier as we consider - continue tonight, no one can shoulder the responsibilities of chairman and CEO forever, sage words from Jack Ma. He has built a $400 million business from his apartment, and now he's leaving Alibaba.

And get your phones ready. That's mine over there, where is it? It's over there. I'll be asking you to weigh in on Elon Musk's future at Tesla after he made strange promises and ideas and then smoked a joint on radio.

[15:15:00]

Something completely different, absolutely new, we have never done anything like this before and few would be quite so brave, some might say foolish, but here on international television, you are going to have a say on what we are doing and it all requires you to get your phone, your tablet, your computer and whatever electronic device you've got and go to cnn.com/join. Now, as you'll see here from my phone, this is what you see, well that might be a little bit tricky for you to see. So let me show you over here.

This is the gist of it. You're going to see the question and today's question is Tesla's CEO, Elon Musk is showing and we'll discuss it. We will show you the results and the percentages of what people believe. Now, the question, and how we're getting to the question, so far, Les Moonves has been pushed out - that was on top of our program. Jack Ma is leaving while on top, so you have two CEOs going in dignity, grace and delight or not in the case of Moonves, Jack Ma absolutely, he's going in his own terms.

So, let's put it to the Board members. And you are the Board in this particular case, what should Elon Musk do? What should Tesla do with Elon Musk? Firstly, they should stay the course with him, stay with it. He should resign or be forced to resign, a bit like Moonves and go off with all of your stock options and your money, and he should be fired, out the door, out the window because of course of what he did - smoking a joint on national radio saying, "I'm going to take the company private," and then not finding he couldn't do it. Thirdly, all the other weird and wonderful eccentric, bizarre things. What should he did? I'll show you the results. cnn.com/join.

From sporty jock to tech billionaire, Jack Ma's remarkable journey as the leader of Alibaba is coming to an end. Next year, he will hand over the reins to Daniel Zhang - the company's Chief Executive will take over Ma's position as Chairman. Investors don't want to see him go. News of his retirement on Wall Street put a minor dent into the shares.

Ma's departure comes in a turbulent time for Alibaba. Its stock has lost around 10% of its value over the year, as China's tech industry grapples with trade tensions and tighter regulations. In his native China, Ma has become a business icon. Matt Rivers reports on his legacy from Beijing.

(BEGIN VIDEO TAPE)

JACK MA, CHAIRMAN, ALIBABA: No banks would accept it ...

MATT RIVERS, CORRESPONDENT, CNN: Jack Ma, one of China's richest men, a giant in tech, a man who has stood side by side with presidents, loves kung-fu novels, always has. He has a genre called Wu-xia and he says, they teach valuable lessons.

MA: Whenever you want to be a great people, a great company, you have to work very hard. You have to suffer a lot of terrible things -- wraths and terrible things -- before you be a hero. It is spiritual. It is spiritual. And think out of box. You have to think out of box to win.

RIVERS: And win he has. It's been 19 years since he co-founded, Alibaba and the company that began in a Hangzou, China apartment has grown into one of the largest internet companies in the world.

[15:20:01]

RIVERS: In 2014, Alibaba $25 billion IPO was then the largest in US history. Ant Financial, the company's finance subsidiary has invested billions of dollars in companies around the globe. Alibaba's e-commerce sites have fundamentally changed the way hundreds of millions of people shop in China and its mobile payment platform revolutionized how people pay for what they buy.

All the while, Ma has arguably become the most public face of China's tech boom, a charismatic, often inspiring figure for ordinary people; nicknamed Papa Ma on Chinese internet.

Ma has faced his share of criticism of course. Critics say, his company nearly copied e-Bay, and thrived only because the Communist Party wanted it, too. China's protectionist policies, so the argument goes, ensured that Alibaba had no real competition making its rise not only easier, but in some ways inevitable.

There is some truth there, but no matter your view, the facts remain. Alibaba is a juggernaut of a company and its leader is routinely mentioned in the same sentence as other (inaudible) of tech - think Jobs, or Musk, or Gates, and like Gates, Ma says life is about more than a job.
