urn:contentItem:5T6P-2H51-JB20-G0MJ-00000-00I Am Part of the Resistance Inside the Trump Administration; Booker Releases Kavanaugh Documents But GOP Insists They Were Already Cleared; Republican Demands More Documents Over Alleged FISA Abuses; Sessions To Meet State Attorneys General About Social Media Crackdown; Gary Busey On Tell-All Book2018-09-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:40ZLexisNexisKENNEDY8:00 PM ESTKmele Foster, Chris Barron; Gary BuseyNEWSFinancial090601cb.234I Am Part of the Resistance Inside the Trump Administration; Booker Releases Kavanaugh Documents But GOP Insists They Were Already Cleared; Republican Demands More Documents Over Alleged FISA Abuses; Sessions To Meet State Attorneys General About Social Media Crackdown; Gary Busey On Tell-All BookLisa Kennedy Montgomery, Ed Henry, Shannon Bream, Tom Shillue, Steve Hilton

LISA KENNEDY MONTGOMERY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: President Trump on the war path. He's furious over the anonymous New York Times op-ed still mad to reportedly written by a senior Trump administration official. But what does that mean? He is demanding the paper reveal their source. His allies are now doing the same. But will the old gray lady blink as you know the Times yesterday published the op-ed and the author claim the president is unfit for office and that a number of staffers are doing everything they can to protect the nation from the president.

As we speak, the hunt is on for the so-called mole and now the list of senior officials denying it's them continues to grow. Everyone from the vice president to the Secretary of State, the Secretary of Defense, even Ben Carson, no. I thought it was Ben Carson. In a scathing statement, White Press Secretary Sarah Sanders said, "For those of you asking for the identity of the anonymous coward, the media is wild obsession with, the identity of the unanimous coward is recklessly tarnishing the reputation of thousands of great Americans who proudly serve our country and work for President Trump. Stop. If you want to know who this gutless loser is, call the opinion desk of the failing NYT and ask them. Sanders continued, they're the only one complicit in this deceitful act. We stand united together and fully support our President Donald J. Trump."

The op-ed also claims some senior officials have mulled the idea of invoking the 25th Amendment to remove Trump from office. And now, oh, Massachusetts Democratic Senator Elizabeth Warren has jumped on that bandwagon telling CNN, "If senior administration officials think the President of the United States is not able to do his job, then they should invoke the 25th Amendment." The president has also been a master at beating back crisis after crisis.

Will he prevail once again? Joining me now Fox News Chief National Correspondent, Ed Henry.

ED HENRY, FOX NEWS CHIEF NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: Spoiler alert, yes. The -- no. He'll prevail again.

MONTGOMERY: Oh, he will prevail.

HENRY: We -- a crisis -- there's a crisis. Every day there's a crisis.

MONTGOMERY: Every day there's a crisis. This, you know, I'm going to be a little bit cynical here. I talked to with Corey Lewandowski last night about this and floated the idea that maybe this whole thing is a ruse and - -

(CROSSTALK)

HENRY: By someone inside the White house?

MONTGOMERY: By someone inside the White House at the direction of the president in order to get the Woodward --

HENRY: I don't believe that. But it's an interesting theory simply because what this is doing is rallying the president's base and saying, there is a deep state. You put together the Woodward book, you put together this anonymous op-ed, you mentioned the great lady. This almost never happen an idea of an anonymous op-ed. Put your name to it. If this is really happening now --

(CROSSTALK)

MONTGOMERY: And have some journalistic standards if you're going to publish something like that and demand that this person comes forward.

HENRY: My favorite part of the op-ed was when the anonymous author referred to an anonymous official inside the White House who was outraged that at a recent meeting the president at the last minute reversed himself on basically an anonymous policy. It didn't even say it was education bill, the healthcare bill. They said he reverse -- so you had an anonymous person about an anonymous person about an anonymous policy.

My point just being if this is really going on behind the scene then people should put their name to it and let's hash it out.

MONTGOMERY: You know what, this is like -- it's like being in Vincent van Gogh's art studio and complaining that his paint strokes are too chunky. Like we know what the process is. We know what the outcome is and we don't --

(CROSSTALK)

HENRY: -- is a very serious thing. It would be at least more than half. So a majority of the senior officers I think the constitution says that the amendment to the constitution says would have to go to the president pro tem of the Senate and say the president cannot perform his duties, basically the cabinet. More than half the cabinet. And while there has been these little rumors about it, there's really been no serious effort by the cabinet to do this.

And that's why I think you're seeing, you know, many cabinet people like James Mattis who has respect of leaders in both parties saying this is not true.

MONTGOMERY: Yes. And I think that there are enough people who want to just see the end of this president's term. And I mean it's exhausting work and It doesn't matter who the president is like half of this people are bound to quit in 2020.

HENRY: If there's the other thing, if Elizabeth Warren were to get her way and the 25th Amendment is invoke and the president is gone, Vice President Pence becomes the president and that's someone that Democrats don't want --

(CROSSTALK)

MONTGOMERY: -- critical point. That's the one person on earth she doesn't want to be president. But I really think there is so much delusion here that people think that Hillary Clinton is going to be president. That somehow there was a bad call in the U.S. Open and the umpire has been overthrown and, you know, Roger Federer somehow --

(CROSSTALK)

HENRY: -- we have this, you know, instant replay mentality perhaps. You're right. And it was Robert Reich, the Labor Secretary of the Clinton administrator recently called it he wants an annulment that basically it never happened the election of Donald Trump and so you would not just by his estimation remove him. This is serious. He said --

(CROSSTALK)

MONTGOMERY: Like a Catholic marriage? Come on.

HENRY: And you would remove him from office, but you also wipe out the executive orders, the tax cuts, that basically never happened. Come on.

MONTGOMERY: I mean but that is in and of itself a symptom of severe psychological condition. Someone who really thinks that you can just wave your magic wand because you don't like the outcome with an election. There are things that the president does that I don't like. You know, I think there are a lot of things that he does that are very, very distracting. And, you know, there are some things in this op-ed that are true that if you just look at the president's record and took his temperament out of it, yes, he would be more popular.

But he's also historically not that unpopular.

HENRY: And when you go back to your theory about could someone in the White House have sort of leaked this op-ed or done this op-ed to distract or anything? I think what else is going on. Well, again, I don't believe that theory. It's interesting because another story got overshadow this week that Bob Mueller according to the New York Times has privately said to the president's legal team, never mind about an interview over Russian collusion.

You can basically do it in writing. That means he has nothing probably on Russian collusion. That is a big deal. It makes it less and less likely he'll be impeached --

(CROSSTALK)

MONTGOMERY: Or a perjury trap also isn't a critical element because that means that the Mueller team has internalize that you can't indict a sitting president and they don't have enough to --

HENRY: Correct. And, oh, by the way, while we're talking about all this other stuff, Brett Kavanaugh is about to be confirmed to the Supreme Court.

MONTGOMERY: No. The president Cory Booker has his way.

HENRY: So that would be two Supreme Court justices in a year and a half. And so my point being while many of the media folks and it was chaos and crisis as you said at the top. The president is getting the stuff done.

MONTGOMERY: And that's a perfect transition. Ed Henry, thank you so much.

HENRY: Good to see you.

MONTGOMERY: Great to see you in New York. Now, meantime, another shocking day in that very Kavanaugh confirmation hearing. Here's a live look inside, yes. It's still going on. But today with New Jersey Democratic Senator Cory Booker's grandstanding that absolutely stole the show. Core Bear, where are you?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. CORY BOOKER (D), NEW JERSEY: I'm going to release the e-mail about racial profiling and I understand that penalty comes with potential ousting from the Senate. And if Senator Cornyn believes that I violated Senate rules, I openly invite and accept the consequences.

SEN. JOHN CORNYN (R-TX), SENATE MAJORITY WHIP: Running for president is no excuse for violating the rules of the Senate. No senator deserves to sit on this committee or serve in the senate in my view if they decide to be a law under themselves and willingly flout the rules of the senate and the determination of confidentiality.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MONTGOMERY: The left is screaming go Cory. Give it to the GOP with your liberal sib. But here's the thing, that entire dramatic rant was nothing but a bunch of baloney. Cory's so-called confidential documents were cleared for release last night. So the whole thing was only for the cameras. He even called it his Spartacus moment. It was a farticus moment. Will this overshadow the actual hearing? Joining me now from "FOX NEWS @ NIGHT", it's host, Shannon Bream in D.C. live with the latest.

Shannon, welcome back. It's so nice to see you.

SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS CHANNEL HOST: Always great to be with you, Kennedy.

MONTGOMERY: So, Cory booker did not violate the rules of the Senate but he pretended he did.

BREAM: There's so much to unpack here. So I will tell you when we first saw him having this interchange with Senator Cornyn. I must call him Justice Cornyn. But he was a Supreme Court justice in Texas, not here in D.C. But those two were really going back and forth. But what we later learned and even after that Senator Booker left the room. One of our producers caught up with him and got him on camera because Cornyn said, you know, you're violating the rules and Cory Booker then made a multiple statements about bring it on.

Come after me. I can't wait to see if you actually do it. Then we learned not long after that, he knew all along according to the chairman of the senate committee, senator --sorry. There's another protester back there. But that's become the norm here. Senator Chuck Grassley though said, listen, it was around 4:00 in the morning that they notified them these documents were free for public release. So hours before he had this little showdown with Senator Cornyn, he apparently knew that those documents were completely cleared, so while he's talked about it, I'm willing to risk exposing for the senate.

Back at it, I asked his staff multiple times when he knew they would not give me a time. But they said, listen, he's going to continue to do this. urn:contentItem:5YXS-BWJ1-JCMN-Y51M-00000-00'I am truly sorry': Read the full email Uber's CEO sent employees after laying off 25% of the company's staff in 2 weeks (UBER)2020-05-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:40ZLexisNexis'I am truly sorry': Read the full email Uber's CEO sent employees after laying off 25% of the company's staff in 2 weeks (UBER)Julie Bort

May 18, 2020( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) ; Uber on Monday announced it was cutting 3,000 more jobs,[1] bringing the total layoffs this month to 6,700.In an email to staff, CEO Dara Khosrowshahi outlined other restructuring efforts, like closing offices and slowing investments.Investors cheered the layoffs, sending Uber's stock price up more than 6% in trading Monday.Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories[2]. Uber on Monday confirmed Business Insider's reporting that it plans to lay off 3,000 more workers in addition to its previous round of 3,700 job cuts earlier in May.[3]Together, the layoffs represent about a quarter of the company's entire global workforce, which stood at 28,600 at the end of March.In an email to staff obtained by Business Insider, Uber's chief executive, Dara Khosrowshahi, said he consulted with leaders at other companies to see if there was a better option.Ultimately, however, he said the impact of the coronavirus pandemic — which has sent ride requests on Uber's app plunging as much as 80% across the board — required direct action to cut costs. He also outlined the severance packages the company will provide to affected employees, and detailed new restructuring efforts designed to further save money.Investors cheered the announcement, which Uber said would save more than $1 billion in planned spending.

Uber's stock price gained 6% in trading Monday compared to Friday's close. Here's Khosrowshahi's full email to staff: Subject: A very difficult day, and what's nextTeam Uber:These have been unprecedented and challenging times for everyone—our societies, our governments, our families, our economies, all around the world. They've also been challenging for Uber, and many of you, as you've waited for us to define the road ahead. I've said clearly that we had to take tough action to resize our company to the new reality of our business, and that I would come back to you this week with the specifics.Today I have the specifics: we have made the incredibly difficult decision to reduce our workforce by around 3,000 people, and to reduce investments in several non-core projects. As a leadership team we had to take the time to make the right decisions, to ensure that we are treating our people well, and to make certain that we could walk you through our decision making in the sort of detailed and transparent manner you deserve.Where we started and hard choicesWe began 2020 on an accelerated path to total company profitability. Then the coronavirus hit us with a once-in-a-generation public health and economic crisis. People are rightfully staying home, and our Rides business, our main profit generator, is down around 80%. We're seeing some signs of a recovery, but it comes off of a deep hole, with limited visibility as to its speed and shape.You've heard me say it before: hope is not a strategy. While that's easy to say, the truth is that this is a decision I struggled with. Our balance sheet is strong, Eats is doing great, Rides looks a little better, maybe we can wait this damn virus out...I wanted there to be a different answer. Let me talk to a few more CEOs...maybe one of them will tell me some good news, but there simply was no good news to hear. Ultimately, I realized that hoping the world would return to normal within any predictable timeframe, so we could pick up where we left off on our path to profitability, was not a viable option.I knew that I had to make a hard decision, not because we are a public company, or to protect our stock price, or to please our Board or investors. I had to make this decision because our very future as an essential service for the cities of the world—our being there for millions of people and businesses who rely on us—demands it. We must establish ourselves as a self-sustaining enterprise that no longer relies on new capital or investors to keep growing, expanding, and innovating.We have to take these hard actions to stand strong on our own two feet, to secure our future, and to continue on our mission.I know that none of this will make it any easier for our friends and colleagues affected by the actions we are taking today. To those of you personally impacted, I am truly sorry. I know this will cause pain for you and your families, especially now. Many of you will be affected not because of the quality of your work, but because of strategic decisions we made to discontinue certain areas of activity, or projects that are no longer necessary, or simply because of the stark reality we face. You have been a huge part of this company and every day forward we will build on the foundations that you established, brick by brick.Our decisions and the road forwardWe have decided to re-focus our efforts on our core. If there is one silver lining regarding this crisis, it's that Eats has become an even more important resource for people at home and for restaurants; and delivery, whether of groceries or other local goods, is not only an increasing part of everyday life, it is here to stay. We no longer need to look far for the next enormous growth opportunity: we are sitting right on top of one. I will caution that while Eats growth is accelerating, the business today doesn't come close to covering our expenses. I have every belief that the moves we are making will get Eats to profitability, just as we did with Rides, but it's not going to happen overnight.So we need to fundamentally change the way we operate. We need to make some really hard decisions about what we will and won't do going forward, based on a few principles: We are organizing around our core: helping people move, and delivering things.We are building a cost-efficient structure that avoids layers and duplication and can scale, at speed.We are being intentional with our location strategy focused on key markets/hubs. Mac will now lead a unified Mobility team, which will include Rides and, as of today, Transit. Mac will continue to manage our cross-cutting functions like Safety & Insurance, CommOps, U4B, and Business Development, the latter of which will be centralized across Rides, Eats, andGiven the necessary cost cuts and the increased focus on core, we have decided to wind down the Incubator and AI Labs and pursue strategic alternatives for Uber Works. Due to these decisions, Zhenya has decided it makes sense to move on from Uber. Zhenya is customer-centric to core, and I am deeply grateful for all of her hard work.We are also looking at our geographic footprint. While it served us well for many years to cast a wide physical net, it's time to be more intentional about where we have employees on the ground. We are closing or consolidating around 45 office locations globally, including winding down Pier 70 in San Francisco and moving some of those colleagues to our new HQ in SF. And over the next 12 months we will begin the process of winding down our Singapore office and moving to a new APAC hub in a market where we operate our services.Having learned my own personal lesson about the unpredictability of the world from the punch-in-the-gut called COVID-19, I will not make any claims with absolute certainty regarding our future. I will tell you, however, that we are making really, really hard choices now, so that we can say our goodbyes, have as much clarity as we can, move forward, and start to build again with confidence.How we are helping departing employeesAs we previewed last week, we have taken a lot of feedback and worked to provide strong severance benefits and other support for those leaving Uber, like healthcare coverage and an alumni talent directory. We're also taking care to support people in special situations a bit differently, like those on US visas or parental leaves. While the details will differ slightly by country, you can see a summary here. Every departing employee will have a 1:1 to receive the details of their individual package.Given the global nature of these changes, and the local rules and regulations involved, the individual experience today will vary by country:If you are one of the many affected Uber teammates, I'll acknowledge right here that any package we offer, regardless of how thoughtful or generous, will never replace the opportunity to belong, to make a difference, to establish the kinds of bonds you establish with any important company or cause. We wouldn't be here without you. We will finish what you started, and we will be excited to see the great things that you will build next.I am incredibly thankful to *everyone* reading this email, because the resilience and grit you've shown has made Uber the company it is and will continue to be. I've never had a harder day professionally than today, but Uber has consistently surprised me with the challenges it has thrown my way. But it's the toughest challenges that are worthwhile, and I know even more strongly in my heart than I ever have that Uber is worth it, and more.Dara Loading Something is loading. urn:contentItem:4690-YHF0-003M-X272-00000-00IBD'S 20 RULES FOR INVESTMENT SUCCESS2002-07-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:40ZLexisNexisB; Pg. 16IBD'S 20 RULES FOR INVESTMENT SUCCESSBy, Investor's Business Daily

A vital point is these rules are not based on our personal opinion, our beliefs or those of Wall Street's analysts and experts. Investor's Business Daily built models of the most successful stocks and investors of the last half-century. We analyzed all their common characteristics, what variables occurred before the best stocks had huge advances and how these variables changed when the stocks topped. So these rules and principles represent how the market actually works. If you ignore them and rely instead on personal opinions, feelings or emotions, you are potentially arguing with how the market has functioned for 50 years and you will likely make more costly mistakes. 1. Consider buying stocks with each of the last three years' earnings up 25%+, return on equity of 17%+ and recent earnings and sales accelerating. 2. Recent quarterly earnings and sales should be up 25% or more. 3. Avoid cheap stocks. Buy stocks selling at $ 15 a share and higher. 4. Learn how to use charts to spot sound bases and exact buy points. Confine buys to these points as stocks break out on big volume increases. 5. Cut every loss when it's 8% below your cost. Make no exceptions so you can always avoid huge, damaging losses. Never average down in price. 6. Have selling rules on when to sell and take profit on the way up. Review "When to Sell and Take a Profit" in "How to Make Money in Stocks." 7.

Buy when market indexes are in an uptrend. Reduce investments and raise cash when general market indexes show five or more days of volume distribution. 8. Read IBD's Investor's Corner and Big Picture columns to learn how to recognize important tops and bottoms in market indexes. 9. Buy stocks with a Relative Price Strength Rating of 85 or higher in the IBD SmartSelect Corporate Ratings. 10. Pick companies with management ownership of stock. 11. Buy mostly in the top six broad industry sectors in IBD's New Highs List. 12. Select stocks with increasing institutional sponsorship in recent quarters. 13. Current quarterly after-tax profit margins should be improving and near their peak. 14. Don't buy because of dividends or P-E ratios. Buy the No. 1 company in an industry in earnings and sales growth, R.O.E., profit margins and product quality. 15. Pick companies with a new product or service. 16. Select mainly New America entrepreneurial companies (those that had an IPO within the last eight years). 17. Check into companies buying back 5% to 10% of their stock and those with new management (what is management's background?). 18. Don't try to bottom guess or buy on the way down. Never argue with the market. Forget your pride and ego. 19. Find out if the market currently favors big-cap or small-cap stocks. 20. Do a post-analysis of all your buys and sells. Post on charts where you bought and sold. Evaluate and develop rules to correct your major mistakes. 3 Are you tempted to buy Nortel Networks, Lucent Technologies or other cheap former highfliers at rock-bottom prices? Be careful. You might get what you pay for. When it comes to investing, it's quality you should be concerned with, not quantity. A $ 2 stock is cheap for a reason. The company usually lacks sales and earnings growth, or has serious financial problems. These companies trade more on promises than performance. The two-year bear market has dragged down prices of past winners. Many big tech and biotech stocks have shed more than 90% of their value to a few dollars, or even pennies. Why? It's usually because the company's fundamentals have slipped. Competition, regulations on the industry and news of SEC probes and accounting scandals can also severely damage these low-priced issues. Instead, most big winners start out at prices between 25 and 50 a share. Companies should have annual earnings and sales growth of 25% or more, new products and be in a leading industry. These qualities are what draw in big institutional support. It's their buying power that moves stocks to new highs. There are more than 3,700 stocks trading under 10 a share in the market today. But finding a diamond among the rubble can be a fruitless task. You're better off buying a few shares of companies that have proven themselves than big blocks of tiny, thinly traded stocks.

urn:contentItem:43P3-HJF0-003M-X4T5-00000-00IBD'S TOP 102001-08-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:40ZLexisNexisA; Pg. 1IBD'S TOP 10By, Investor's Business Daily

A Grim Economic Omen: July Layoff Plans Soared 1U.S. companies said they would cut 205,975 jobs, up 65% from June's figure and 222% from July 2000, says Chicago-based outplacement firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas. It was the biggest one-month tally since Challenger started tracking eight years ago. Telecom, computer and electronics companies accounted for almost half of July's figure. But experts note a layoff announcement isn't a layoff. It could be part of a months-long plan that could change with the economy. California High Court Finds No Liability For Gun Firms 2Victims cannot sue gun makers when criminals use their products illegally, California's top court ruled. It rejected a suit stemming from the 1993 massacre of eight people in a skyscraper. The 5-1 decision was in step with other courts. Every state high court and federal appellate court in the nation to consider such suits has ruled that makers of legal, non-defective guns cannot be sued for their criminal misuse. A lower state appeals court had OK'd such suits. Market In A Deep Snooze, Falls On Comatose Trade 3Traders deserted Wall Street, cutting volume to its lowest full-session level of the year on Nasdaq and one of the year's lowest on the NYSE. The Dow and S&P 500 each sank 1.1%, and the Nasdaq lost 1.6%. Consumer electronics retailers finished as the day's third-worst group after RadioShack reported a 6% drop in July same-store sales. The news whacked Best Buy and others.

Funeral services and office supply stores closed strong as defensive issues hung on to most of the market's top spots. More on A18 Chip Price War Casualties: Intel Goals, Pentium Prices 4Salomon analyst Jon Joseph cut the No. 1 chipmaker's 2001 profit view to 47 cents a share from 54 cents, with consensus views of 51 cents. Lehman analyst Dan Niles lowered forecasts for Intel's average selling price and unit shipments, citing a price war among chipmakers. Joseph slashed 2002 guidance by a nickel to 70 cents. Niles said Intel will cut prices for its high-end Pentium 4 chip by 50% on Aug. 26 and another 10% to 25% on Oct. 28 if demand doesn't pick up. Intel fell 1.40, or 4%, to 30.28.More on A9 EPA Mulls Cut In Number Of Required Gas Blends 5The head of the Environmental Protection Agency is considering reducing the number of gasoline blends used around the country to help promote clean air. In a USA Today interview, EPA administrator Christie Whitman said limiting the number of "boutique blends" to three or four formulas could increase fuel supplies and help prevent large spikes in the prices drivers see at the pump. But, she added, "It is very much a states' rights issue." Cisco 4th-Qtr Report Due, But Outlook Seen Crucial 6Cisco Systems' fiscal fourth-quarter earnings report, due out after Tuesday's close is one of the last big tech earnings reports this summer. But Wall Street will focus on Cisco's guidance for its next fiscal year. Analysts hope for signs of improved demand, but many doubt Cisco will report any pickup. Rival makers haven't seen demand improve much, and may be undercutting Cisco on price. Its router business got a boost due to a new release, but overall demand remains weak. Most analysts expect the company to have "limited visibility" into 2002.More on A6 EchoStar Bids For Hughes, Threatening Murdoch Deal 7EchoStar Communications' $ 32 billion stock offer comes just weeks after Hughes' parent General Motors rejected a prior offer from EchoStar. GM spurned the original offer, in part due to antitrust concerns. GM said last month it was moving forward in talks with Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. to sell Hughes. Hughes' DirecTV is the No. 1 U.S. satellite TV broadcaster, with 10 million customers vs. EchoStar's 6.1 million. IRA's New Arms Proposal Is Hailed As Breakthrough 8The plan wasn't immediately disclosed. Nor did the commission overseeing peace talks say when the outlawed group would start disarming. Protestant politicians who had demanded an actual start expressed doubts the Irish Republican Army had offered enough. "Based on our discussions with the IRA representative, we believe that this proposal initiates a process that will put IRA arms completely and verifiably beyond use," said the panel led by Canadian Gen. John de Chastelain. US Air Rejects Buyout Bid, Saying It Lacks Credibility 9Global Airlines, a holding firm with no flight operations, offered to buy US Airways for $ 1.8 billion, or $ 27 a share. US Airways quickly said it wanted no part of the deal. Analysts gave it little credence as well. Global Airlines, owned entirely by investor Emil Bernard, unsuccessfully tried several times to buy Trans World Airlines before it was sold to American Airlines earlier this year. US Airways and UAL's United Airlines ended a proposed $ 4.3 billion merger pact in July after U.S. regulators challenged the deal. General Dynamics To Buy Motorola Unit For $ 825 Mil 10General Dynamics said Motorola's Integrated Information Systems Group will boost its product offerings for its military and government customers. The unit provides defense customers technologies, products and systems for secure communication systems. The defense contractor expects the unit to generate 2002 sales of $ 830 million. Earnings should get an immediate boost. The deal, which awaits regulatory OK, should close in two months. The business will become a part of General Dynamics' Information Systems & Technology group.

urn:contentItem:4NM7-XXX0-TX4P-W2MM-00000-00IBD'S TOP 102007-05-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:40ZLexisNexisFRONT PAGE NEWSPg. A01IBD'S TOP 10

Stocks Fall Sharply, Trade Rises

1 The stock indexes fell on higher volume, closing at session lows. The Nasdaq took a 1.3% pounding, while the S&P 500 and NYSE composite lost 0.8%. The Dow fell a moderate 0.4%. The small-cap S&P 600 tumbled 1.9%. The 10-year Treasury yield fell 7 basis points to 4.63% on weak economic data. More on this page, B2

Retail Gasoline Prices Top $3

2 The nationwide average price at the pump shot up 10 cents last week to $3.02 a gallon, the most since mid-Aug. Gasoline prices have soared as refinery woes limit already tight supply and demand ramps up for the summer driving season. Gas futures rose 3.4% -- 18.6% in April -- to $2.4405. June gas closed nearly flat Mon. at $2.2594. June crude fell 75 cents to $65.71 a barrel.

Spending Weak, Inflation Cools

3 Personal incomes rose 0.7% in March, the same as in Feb. But consumer spending grew just 0.3%, the weakest since Oct. Inflation-adjusted spending fell 0.2%, the weakest since Sept. '05. But the core PCE deflator, closely watched by the Fed, was essentially flat in March. Core inflation fell to 2.1% from Feb.'s 2.4%. That's just above the Fed's 1%-2% comfort zone. More on this page, A2

Deutsche Boerse Will Buy ISE

4 The No. 2 options market jumped 46% to 66.69 after a Deutsche Boerse affiliate said it'll buy Int'l Securities Exchange for $2.8 bil cash -- $67.50 a share. The deal will merge ISE with derivatives exchange Eurex, a venture of Deutsche Boerse and the Swiss Exchange. The deal is still subject to board and regulatory approval.

High Court Limits Patent Rights

5 The Supreme Court made it easier to toss suits over patents that do not create a genuine innovation. Big tech firms cheered the 9-0 ruling; GE and drug firms opposed it. Also, justices limited suits over software exports, saying Microsoft doesn't owe damages to AT&T for overseas Windows sales. That could help Microsoft appeals of $2 bil in damages in 2 recent patent cases. More on A5

Building, Factory Activity Weak

6 Construction spending rose 0.2% in March after Feb.'s 1.5% gain, as commercial building offset housing's slump. But overall spending fell 2% vs. a year earlier. Meantime, the NAPM-Chicago regional factory index fell to 52.9 in April after spiking to 61.7 in March, though still above the neutral 50. The national ISM manufacturing index is due out on Tue. More on this page, B2

U.S. Deaths In Iraq Rose In April

7 Five U.S. troop deaths last weekend put April's toll at 104, most since Dec.'s 112. At least 102 Iraqis were killed or found dead Mon., including 32 in a suicide bombing at a Shiite funeral. About a dozen blasts were heard late Mon. in Baghdad, apparently from rockets fired toward the Green Zone, AP reported. An Iranian envoy met with Iraq's foreign minister, voicing support for its gov't.

War Panel: Israel PM "A Failure'

8 Israel's Lebanon war commission released a scathing report vs. Ehud Olmert that cast doubt on his political future, but didn't call on him to resign. The gov't-appointed panel accused him of rushing to war with Hezbollah last July. Olmert, who heads the centrist Kadima party, said he wouldn't resign.

5 Get Life For London Bomb Plot

9 A judge sentenced the British citizens to life in prison for plotting to attack targets in London, including a popular nightclub, power plants and shopping mall, with bombs made from a half-ton stockpile of fertilizer. The trial exposed ties between the defendants and the deadly 2005 al-Qaida-linked attack on the city's transit system.

Verizon Beats, Revenue Rises

10 The phone company raised Q1 profit 17.4% to 54 cents a share ex items, beating views by a penny. Revenue grew 6.4% to $22.58 bil. Consumer revenue fell 3.5% to $4.2 bil as Verizon continued to lose residential phone customers to cable TV companies. Meanwhile, the number of its FiOS TV subscribers grew by 141,000 homes to 348,000. More on A5

urn:contentItem:4B1X-XDG0-01J8-W08G-00000-00IBD'S TOP 102003-11-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:40ZLexisNexisSECTION A; NATIONAL EDITION; Pg. A01IBD'S TOP 10

Dollar Plunges To Low Vs. Euro

1 The euro surged to a record high vs. the greenback, fueled by the U.S.' decision to impose new quotas on Chinese textiles, raising fears of increased protectionism. Also, a report showed foreign buys of U.S. Treasuries declined. The euro closed up 2.01 cents to $1.1951. The dollar fell 0.3 yen to 108.35 Japanese yen. More on this page

SEC Chief Outlines Fund Reform

2 William Donaldson told a Senate panel the SEC is weighing a "hard" 4 p.m. Eastern cutoff for buying funds. It'll also form an office to spot trading problems fast. He also outlined fund investor rights, which focus on fair and ethical treatment of investors by fund firms. Treasury Secretary John Snow and Fed chief Alan Greenspan urged stiff penalties for offenders. More on this page

Techs Weigh On Market, Again

3 The market indexes fell for a fourth straight day, with software, storage and fiber-optic stocks among the biggest losers. Gold and gem stocks gained. The S&P 500 and the Dow both shed 0.9%. The Nasdaq lost 1.5% as volume rose; the big-tech Nasdaq 100 sank 2.1%. All closed below their 50-day trend lines. More on this page, B2

Oil Tops $33, An 8-Month High

4 Dec. crude futures surged $1.57 a barrel to $33.30, the highest since a war-jitters March 18 peak of $34.97. Jan. crude rose $1.30 to $32.57. Gasoline led the rally, surging on technicals as well as fear that Houston flooding may have affected refineries there. Traders expect today's energy inventories data to show a big drop in crude and distillate supplies last week. More on B13

Bush To Defend Iraq War On Trip

5 President Bush, who began a four-day trip to Britain amid tight security, is expected to tell skeptical Britons today, "History has shown there are times when countries must use force to defend the peace and to defend values." In Iraq, U.S. jets pounded insurgent positions in the largest bombardment since major hostilities ceased in May.

NYSE Members Approve Reforms

6 They OK'd interim Chairman John Reed's governance reforms, along with eight independent board members, including Madeleine Albright and Herbert Allison. The board of directors will handle regulatory issues. A board of executives, made up of NYSE trading firms, will handle market operations. Some critics wanted a complete split. The SEC must OK the changes.

Key Retailers Cleaned Up In Q3

7 Home Depot earned 50 cents a share, up 25% vs. Q3 '02 and beating views by 4 cents as store improvements paid off. Same-store sales rose 7.8%. Dick's Sporting Goods' profit rose 29% to 18 cents, 2 cents above views. It sees Q4 profit of 91-92 cents. Analysts see 91. Office-supply chain Staples made 33 cents in Q3, up 22% and a penny over views. It backed Q4 forecasts.

House OKs Energy Bill 246-180

8 Lawmakers passed a far-reaching bill with $23.5 bil in tax breaks for fuel companies, sending it to the Senate. The GOP-backed bill offers incentives to boost oil, gas, coal and power production. Many Senate Democrats oppose its limits on MTBE lawsuits, a fuel additive blamed for water contamination. But a key GOP Senator said Democrats don't have the votes to filibuster.

Oct. Consumer Prices Were Flat

9 Energy prices dived 3.9%, offsetting a beef-led 0.6% rise in food prices. Core consumer prices, which exclude energy and food, rose 0.2%. The CPI rose 2% vs. a year ago, the smallest gain since Oct. '02. Core CPI rose 1.3%, just over Sept.'s 37-year low. Service prices rose 3.2% vs. a year ago; goods prices climbed 0.5%. See Vital Signs on A2

Gay Marriage Ban Struck Down

10 Massachusetts' top court ruled 4-3 the state's same-sex marriage ban is unconstitutional. It gave lawmakers 180 days to fix the problem. Gay-marriage advocates said the case went past a '99 Vermont high court ruling that led to civil unions there. But Massachusetts' legislature has been mulling a constitutional amendment to define marriage as one man, one woman.

urn:contentItem:4VJ3-9N80-TX4P-W14W-00000-00IBD'S TOP 102009-02-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:40ZLexisNexisFRONT PAGE NEWSPg. A01IBD'S TOP 10

Executive Salary Cap Tied To Aid

1 Pres. Obama imposed a $500,000 salary limit for companies receiving future federal bailouts, saying Americans are upset with "executives being rewarded for failure." The cap would be partly symbolic except for firms that require "exceptional" assistance. The move is part of a bank rescue plan overhaul due next week. More on this page

Major Indexes Surrender Gains

2 The Nasdaq, up 2.2% early on a decent service-sector reading, closed off 0.1%. The S&P 500 slid 0.7% and the NYSE composite 0.5%. The Dow lost 1.5%, hurt by B- ofA, Kraft and Disney. The market faded amid uncertainty about a new financial rescue plan. Volume rose, adding to the session's weak tone. More on this page, B2

Cisco Falls On Q3 Sales Outlook

3 The networking gear giant's shares fell 4% late after predicting sales this quarter will fall 15%-20% vs. views of an 11% year-over-year decline. The tech bellwether said Q2 EPS fell 16% to 32 cents ex items, beating lowered views by 2 cents. Sales sank 7.5% to $9.1 bil, edging views. Cisco is the first big tech firm to post results that include much of Jan. More on A4

Key Service-Sector Index Rises

4 ISM's Jan. nonmanufacturing index unexpectedly climbed to 42.9 from 40.1 in Dec. and 37.4 in Nov. That's far below a neutral 50 reading. But a slower rate of decline is a necessary, if insufficient, step to a bottom. The jobs subindex showed no improvement though. Services account for 80% of U.S. economic activity. More on this page, A2

Senate OKs Home-Buy Incentive

5 The Senate voted to give a tax break of up to $15,000 to homebuyers in hopes of reviving housing, a victory for Republicans eager to leave their mark on the mammoth stimulus bill, which now tops $900 bil. Obama warned of a "catastrophe" without quick action -- even as he signaled a willingness to curb some spending in the bill.

Costco Warns, Retailers Down

6 The wholesale club sees Q2 EPS well below views of 70 cents, after it cut prices in the holiday season. Costco Wholesale's Jan. same-store sales fell 2% as shoppers avoided nonessentials like jewelry. Falling gas prices also hurt. Costco shares sank 7% to a 3-year low. Most other retailers also sold off. Most chains report Jan. sales figures on Thu.

Heavy Job Losses Seen In Jan.

7 Private employers shed 522,000 jobs after slashing 659,000 in Dec., the ADP Employment Survey estimated. Economists expect the BLS to report Fri. that nonfarm payrolls fell by about half a million for a 2 nd straight month. Meanwhile, announced layoff plans soared to a 7-year high last month. Also, Panasonic said it'll slash 15,000 jobs, half in Japan. More on this page, A2

Whistleblower: Madoff Had Help

8 Harry Markopolos, a private fraud examiner who urged the SEC for years to investigate Bernard Madoff, told Congress 14 "feeder funds" participated in his alleged $50 bil Ponzi scheme, funneling investors' money to Madoff in return for fees. Markopolos also railed against the SEC, charging that regulators are "undereducated" and afraid to investigate prominent figures.

Consumer Firms Guide '09 Low

9 Food makers Kraft and Sara Lee fell 9% and 7%, respectively, as they cut their '09 EPS outlooks, saying customers are paring buys and selecting more private-label products. Policymakers and regulators worldwide should help shape an orderly modernisation and digitisation of the financial sector to address the opportunities and risks associated with big techs’ increasing role in financial services according to a new report by t...

Policymakers and regulators worldwide should help shape an orderly modernisation and digitisation of the financial sector to address the opportunities and risks associated with big techs’ increasing role in financial services according to a new report by the International Banking Federation (IBFed) and global management consulting firm Oliver Wyman . The report makes three distinct sets of recommendations: revising measures within financial regulation, strengthening the policy response on themes that cut across industries, and extending finance-specific regulations to other industries where inconsistencies in regulation and enforcement have emerged. Hannah Gurga, Managing Director, Digital Technology & Cyber, UK Finance, said: Technology is transforming many aspects of our lives, including the way we choose to bank and manage our finances. Across the banking and finance sector, firms are investing in new technologies and partnering with fintech operators to develop products and services that better meet the needs of their customers. The entry of big tech into financial services creates new opportunities, but it also brings new risks. As we embark on this next market evolution, consideration is now needed as to how best to maintain the stability, resilience, and consumer protections that are so integral to the banking system.

urn:contentItem:5XFB-49N1-JCDN-12MY-00000-00IBM, Bank of America team up to launch financial services-specific cloud2019-11-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:40ZLexisNexisBUSINESSIBM, Bank of America team up to launch financial services-specific cloud

REUTERS: International Business Machines Corp said on Wednesday that it has built financial services-specific cloud technology in collaboration with Bank of America Corp , which will be the first major bank to use the platform. The public platform, IBM's first industry-specific cloud, is designed to meet the high regulatory, security and resiliency standards required of the financial services industry. "By setting a standard that addresses the concern of hosting highly confidential information, we aim to drive the public cloud to a safety level that is unmatched," said Cathy Bessant, chief operations and technology officer of Bank of America.

Bank of America has focused on its internal cloud computing capabilities. Over the past several years the second largest U.S. bank has gotten down to about 70,000 servers from over 200,000 and trimmed its data centers to 23 from 67. Streamlining those operations has saved US$2 billion annually, Chief Executive Brian Moynihan said on an earnings call last month. However, the bank still relies on cloud services from external vendors since third parties can usually offer the service 23per cent-30per cent cheaper, he said. "We don't need to own the hardware," he said. "We just need to find out who can provide it the right way." Investing in cloud computing is key for banks as more transactions become digital. It is critical that the platform can transfer information quickly, keep data private, and prevent service outages. Bank of America customers reported trouble accessing online banking and card services late last month, according to Downdetector.com. Cloud services used by banks have come under scrutiny in Washington after a massive data breach at Capital One Financial Corp raised questions over the risks posed by banks' reliance on third-party cloud providers. U.S. lawmakers have asked regulators to consider direct oversight of the cloud services big tech companies provide to banks - like Amazon.com Inc's Amazon Web Services, Microsoft Corp's Microsoft Azure and Alphabet Inc's Google Cloud - saying they have become a critical component of the global financial system. IBM was not one of the cloud providers mentioned in the letter. (Reporting by Imani Moise; Editing by Leslie Adler) - Reuters

Sep. 15, 2010 (Xconomy delivered by Newstex) --
  deals,   acquisitions,   Software   Gregory T. Huang wrote:
Waltham, MA-based   OpenPages, a maker of business software for managing corporate risk and compliance activities, is being acquired by IBM (NYSE:IBM) for an undisclosed sum. Armonk, NY-based IBM announced the news in a   press release this morning.



Once the acquisition closes, IBM (NYSE: IBM) says it will integrate OpenPages into its Business Analytics software portfolio. This will be Big Blues 17th acquisition of a Massachusetts-based company since 2003. The most recent one”marketing and Web analytics firm Unica (NASDAQ:   UNCA)”   was announced last month.

OpenPages was founded in 1996 (and formerly called American Computer Innovators). The company started out making content management software, but is now a leader in the field of governance, risk management, and compliance”software that helps businesses comply with regulations to be more transparent and accountable. It has raised an undisclosed amount of venture funding from Goldman Sachs(NYSE:GS) , Globespan Capital Partners, Matrix Partners, Mesirow Financial, Sigma Partners and North Hill Ventures.

OpenPages has more than 200 corporate customers, including Allianz, Barclays (NYSE:BCS) , Carnival Corporation(NYSE:CCL) , Duke Energy (NYSE:DUK PRA) (NYSE:DUK) , SunTrust, TIAA CREF and Williams. IBM and OpenPages previously have worked together on risk management software for the banking, financial services, and insurance industries.

œThe combination of IBM and OpenPages software, business process insights, and industry expertise will help businesses œtackle their complex risk challenges, said OpenPages CEO Michael Duffy, in a statement.

Big tech companies across the board are paying more attention to governance and risk management as a business. In January, Hopkinton, MA-based EMC (NYSE:   EMC)   acquired Archer Technologies and said it would integrate the compliance company within its RSA security division. Other companies in the sector include eIQ Networks, Lumigent, Protiviti, and giants like Oracle, SAP, and Microsoft. (NASDAQ:MSFT)

urn:contentItem:5W4X-MGR1-JD3N-52TK-00000-00IBM calls for ethical approach to artificial intelligence2019-05-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:40ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 20IBM calls for ethical approach to artificial intelligenceSUPRATIM ADHIKARI, EXCLUSIVE

The technology industry needs to get its act together on the ethical development of artificial intelligence to repair its damaged reputation, according to IBM Australia boss David La Rose, who has warned the lack of transparency risks a regulatory backlash.

Speaking to The Australian ahead of IBM's Think Summit this week, Mr La Rose said technology companies had to take the lead when it came to explaining the algorithms that underpinned AI platforms and how they are used.

"The industry has an image problem when it comes to ethics around AI and we have a responsibility here to help our clients with what ethical AI engagement looks like," he said.

"It's incumbent upon us to provide the literacy around AI." While the likes of Microsoft, Google and IBM have AI ethics initiatives in place, self-regulation has so far failed to quell concerns of critics, who say that big tech can't be trusted to police itself.

With regulators globally already looking to stymie the dominance of pervasive technology platforms, like Facebook and Google, Mr La Rose said that the development and implementation of AI technology could not be done behind closed doors.

"AI systems must be transparent and explainable. If we want the public to trust us and not be seen as 'big tobacco' we must be transparent.

"What goes into the algorithm must be made clear and we have to ensure that there's no bias in the recommendations," he said. With the technology sector by and large failing the test on ethical collection and use of personal user data, Mr La Rose said companies would need to do better with AI.

"It's up to governments to regulate but we don't think that's necessarily helpful. Engaging in open dialogue with a set of principles could be more useful in this space. Regulation can't deliver the solution to every problem.

"Ethics is a new area for us but it needs to be addressed now and the conversation needs to take into account factors like available technical skills. Australia is certainly well behind on that front from where we should be," he added.

With no dedicated AI strategy in place in Australia, the latest research from professional services firm Deloitte shows the country is behind China, Germany and the US on effectively leveraging AI technologies. The skills gap is a major concern in Australia, with 72 per cent of organisations citing it as a key deficiency.

The 2018-19 federal budget has allocated $29.9 million over four years to boost Australia's AI capabilities, including development of a technology road map to build standards and ethics. However, it's a fraction of the billions of dollars being invested in China, US and France.

Mr La Rose said that building the right frameworks would require more than just money.

"This is not a technology talent, it's a human challenge and it's up to us, the industry, to take the front foot," he said.

IBM's position is at odds with Amazon, which doesn't have concrete ethical guiding principles in place and instead lets its customers decide how they use its AI tools.

"Organisations like Amazon are entitled to their point of view but we are interested in finding like-minded organisations to have the dialogue with," Mr La Rose said.

"Some organisations are misinterpreting certain elements of AI and it's up to us to go and educate them. We need to change the way we approach the whole topic of ethics and that can't be done without consultation.

"While some technology companies feel they are not ready for this confirmation, we are," he added.

A consultative process and guidelines would be important pillars in building the future framework for how AI technology affected the public, but ethics needed to be more than just another box to tick for organisations, Mr La Rose said.

"Ethics needs to be embedded in everything, from research and development to how we engage with our customers and educate the public on the use of the technology.

"The outcomes need to be clear and we need to base our conversation on the ethical guidelines that are being put in place," he said."This is not a future problem. It's something we need to do now."

Nov 06, 2019( Axios: https://link.axios.com/join/am-signup?source=aci Delivered by Newstex) IBM, one of several Big Tech companies selling facial recognition programs, is calling on Congress to regulate the technology — but not too much.Why it matters: China has built a repressive surveillance apparatus with facial recognition; now, some U.S. cities are rolling it out[1] for law enforcement. But tech companies worry that opponents will react to these developments by kiboshing thetechnology completely.The big picture: IBM's proposal joins calls for federal facial recognition regulations from Microsoft[2], Amazon[3] and the U.S. Chamber of Commerce[4]. Big Tech is threatened by a yearlong groundswell of bans and proposed restrictions on facial recognition bubbling up in cities like San Francisco[5] and states like Massachusetts[6].The companies say these moves would cut off beneficial uses of the technology, like speeding up airport security or finding missing children.Yes, but: They stand to gain from keeping the market open. What's happening: In a white paper shared first with Axios[7], IBM is calling for what it calls "precision regulation."

That means limiting potentially harmful uses rather than forbidding use of the technology entirely. IBM proposes treating various kinds of facial recognition differently. Face detection software, which simply counts the number of faces in the scene, is less prone to abuse than face matching, which can pick specific people out of a crowd."There will always be use cases that will be off-limits," IBM chief privacy officer Christina Montgomery tells Axios. "That includes mass surveillance and racial profiling." At issue is public trust in facial recognition. Companies hope that curtailing some uses will rescue the technology from sliding into pariah status. According to a Morning Consult/Politico poll this summer, two-fifths of Americans support the technology[8], down from nearly half of Americans a year before."Absent the trust, you're going to see calls for bans," Montgomery says. Details: IBM calls for three policies it says are ready to be implemented immediately. Requiring notice and consent for people subject to facial recognition authentication, such as in a workplace or on a social media platform.Implementing export controls that prevent the sale of facial matching technology — the kind police could use to pick wanted criminals out of a crowd.Mandating that law enforcement disclose facial recognition technology and publish regular transparency reports. For big companies, overseas businessinterests can complicate matters. In its white paper, IBM says companies "must be accountable for ensuring they don't facilitate human rights abuses by deploying technologies such as facial matching in regimes known for human rights violations."Earlier this year, BuzzFeed News reported that IBM was among several companies marketing facial recognition[9] in the notoriously repressive[10] United Arab Emirates.IBM says the technology referenced in the BuzzFeed story cannot identify individuals based on their faces. That is, it's not facial matching software. What they're saying: "We're responsible stewards of technology," Montgomery tells Axios. "We vet client engagements at the highest levels of the company."'If adopted, IBM's proposal would clear the way for the deployment of this authoritarian technology in our communities, a move opposed by the public, AI experts and democratically elected legislatures across the United States," says Matt Cagle of the ACLU of Northern California. urn:contentItem:7W6C-99X0-YBK5-D1S0-00000-00IBM Deal; Outrage Over AIG Bonuses; Demanding Justice in AIG; February Consumer Price Index; Fox 50; Interview With Senator Kay Bailey2009-03-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:41ZLexisNexisIBM Deal; Outrage Over AIG Bonuses; Demanding Justice in AIG; February Consumer Price Index; Fox 50; Interview With Senator Kay Bailey

LIZ CLAMAN, FBN ANCHOR: Coming up this morning on MONEY FOR BREAKFAST the uproar over the AIG's bonuses races on. And lawmakers are on the move to retrieve the money.

Drug lords, kidnappings and now trade tariffs is this what we get for the $10 billion in aid the U.S. gives to Mexico? We've got a hot debate straight ahead.

And does IBM have sunny days ahead? If you're just waking up here comes the sun -- IBM wanting to buy Sun Microsystems.

We've got the latest. We're serving all that and so much more for you right here on MONEY FOR BREAKFAST.

Well, good morning everybody. Welcome to a special edition of MONEY FOR BREAKFAST. The AIG America's out outraged. I am Liz Claman. Alexis Glick is off today.

We're going to have much more on all this anger, this drama stemming from the AIG bonuses, and so much of it, we know it's coming from you.

And we actually really do want to hear from you. Are you outraged? But specifically, why? Don't just say, "Yes, I'm furious." We want to know why you're outrage and you can actually email us right here at moneyforbreakfast@foxbusiness.com and we'll actually share those with you later in the show. We'll read what some of you have to say.

But first let's get you caught up on the futures here and this after a day where we had a triple digit gain for the DOW Jones Industrial. Futures are lower today at the moment DOW Jones Industrial futures down 44 but we tend to look more at the S&P futures, they give you a better sense of what might happen with the market, they're down nearly five points; the NASDAQ down four.

Let's send it right now to Connell McShane at the Fox Business desk with the very latest. He's got earnings out from General Mills -- Connell.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: They look a little light, Liz, $3.79 a share X-items has been the number that's been reported by General Mills but the Street's looking for $0.88, so light on that front. Interesting to point out that the company says it's raising its guidance for the full year but when you look at it the guidance is still light, of where the Street estimate is. You see where the stock close yesterday $3.38 to $3.87 for the full year, $3.94 is the estimate. So the top end of the guidance at $3.87 is still light of the estimate.

General Mills among other things talking about currency translations hurting their earnings a little bit, reducing sales growth by three percentage points. The currency translation so GIS, General Mills certainly will a stock to watch today here, Liz. This one is down about 11 percent with the markets so far this year.

But the earnings look light, we'll have more on it later on the morning, right now back over to you.

CLAMAN: Yes, we'll be talking much more about General Mills because clearly you cannot ignore Count Chocolate and Boo Berry. Very important.

MCSHANE: I know it.

CLAMAN: Thank you Connell.

As I mentioned we're taking a closer look at this hour at the outrage over AIG. So let's start with the latest news, first off, Chairman and CEO of American International Group Ed Liddy pulling up a chair at a Congressional witness table today. This one is going to be so closely watched he will take massive heat. I promise you every lawmaker is going to want to make his or her voice heard very loudly, this over the more than $200 million in bonuses.

Meanwhile, Congress and the White House trying to find ways to strip bonus recipients of the money they got. Some of these people are not even with the company anymore and they we're getting millions and million of dollars worth.

The chairman of ranking member of the Senate Finance Committee proposed companies and individuals pay a 35 percent tax on all retention awards and bonuses over $50,000.

And in a letter to Congress, Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner suggesting holding back the bonus amount from upcoming bailout funds for AIG.

There are all kinds of ideas being thrown out here on how to get the money back but do you have ideas, I mean, how angry are you over this bonus debacle? If you are steamed, you're not alone we're not just talking about lawmakers.

Fox Business's senior Washington correspondent, Peter Barnes is in our Washington Bureau with the results -- Peter a new Pew Research Center Poll, boy they gets these things out pretty quickly, what do we see?

PETER BARNES, FBN SENIOR WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: Well that's right, Liz, the AIG bonus controversy a possible big political headache for President Obama if the financial bailout doesn't work and if he has to go back to Congress later for more money to help banks.

The White House continuing to express outrage about the bonuses, distancing itself from the controversy and trying to get out in front of the story that was inevitably going to dominate the headlines anyway.

But the President remains fully vested in a bank rescue plan, he voted for it as a Senator. And as President he says it is critical to reviving bank lending and the economy.

On Monday, the Pew Research Center released the poll that found that 87 percent of people are outright angry about or at least bothered by bank bailouts.

In the poll, despite their anger, people still supported bank rescues as a policy 48 percent to 40 percent. But the poll was taken last week before revelations of the AIG bonuses.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MICHAEL DIMOCK, PEW RESEARCH CENTER: I think if anything this has intensified the emotional feeling that people have. Again, they've been giving a clear example of the downside of this policy the problems with the way that this money is being spent. I think that intensifies the anger now. Whether it's going to undermine the support for the policy, it's something that we're going to need to see how it plays out.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARNES: Now, the President has to be somewhat careful on how he plays the AIG bonus controversy, Dimock says. His job approval rating is starting to slip. The PEW poll shows it down five points from February to March, Dimock says mainly over public concern about his stimulus plan, his budget and how they will increase the deficit as well as some concern over his foreign policy.

But the President did include a $750 billion placeholder in his budget for more funding for bank bailouts if he needs it. Being outraged about how AIG now may leave the President in a delicate political position, later with Congress and voters trying to turn a negative consequence of the bailout, taxpayer money going to big bonuses into a positive, cleaning up the system by continuing those very bailouts.

Liz, back to you.

CLAMAN: There is no way Peter, anybody is going rubber-stamp more spending with these AIG bonuses unless this gets resolved. Unbelievable. Thanks for the PEW Research Center.

BARNES: No way, you're right.

CLAMAN: Yes, here take my money.

BARNES: Yes.

CLAMAN: The AIG bonus was the talk of the halls on Capitol Hill yesterday. Massachusetts Congressman and Chairman of the House Financial Services Committee Barney Frank was confounded by Ed Liddy of AIG's reasoning for payment of the bonuses. Listen in.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. BARNEY FRANK, CHAIRMAN OF THE HOUSE FINANCIAL SERVICES COMMITTEE: Mr. Liddy gave two arguments. One, was my hands are tied legally but the other was a policy argument. He doesn't want to rescind them because he wants to retain those people. I am very skeptical that retaining the people who made the mistakes is a good idea.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CLAMAN: For more on today's hearings and this outrage that we know so many of you are feeling, I am joined now by Democratic Congressman Jim Himes of Connecticut and Republican Congresswoman Shelley Moore Capito of West Virginia. Both served on the House Financial Services Committee.

Well, did you bring your boxing gloves? Both of you, I can only imagine...

REP. JIM HIMES (D), CONNECTICUT: Good morning Liz.

CLAMAN: Ed Liddy sitting in front of you. I will start with the Representative Himes. Give me a sense of what you want and need to hear from Ed Liddy today.

HIMES: Well, you know, as you pointed out in your story the outrage is out there is unbelievable. And you know, Congress represents the people and so I think you are going to see some outrage today.
