LIZ CLAMAN, FBN ANCHOR: Coming up this morning on MONEY FOR BREAKFAST the uproar over the AIG's bonuses races on. And lawmakers are on the move to retrieve the money.

Drug lords, kidnappings and now trade tariffs is this what we get for the $10 billion in aid the U.S. gives to Mexico? We've got a hot debate straight ahead.

And does IBM have sunny days ahead? If you're just waking up here comes the sun -- IBM wanting to buy Sun Microsystems.

We've got the latest. We're serving all that and so much more for you right here on MONEY FOR BREAKFAST.

Well, good morning everybody. Welcome to a special edition of MONEY FOR BREAKFAST. The AIG America's out outraged. I am Liz Claman. Alexis Glick is off today.

We're going to have much more on all this anger, this drama stemming from the AIG bonuses, and so much of it, we know it's coming from you.

An opinion article in "The Wall Street Journal" yesterday said this: "The politicians prefer to talk about AIG's latest bonus payments because they deflect attention from Washington's failure to supervise AIG."

How do you respond to that, Senator?

HUTCHISON: I think it's valid. I think that the regulatory reform that is needed for AIG and for our financial institutions, and for the institutions that are doing all of these fancy derivatives that have been virtually unregulated, must be regulated in a responsible way. We don't want to go overboard, but we certainly know where the vacancies are in our regulatory system today, and we need to address that.

CLAMAN: Senator, one of your constituents just shot us an e-mail, wanted to get it to you. Neil Lewis in Granbury, Texas, says, "Why are we outraged at the bonuses when we are supporting foreign banks to the tunes of tens of billions of dollars?"

Now, just to clarify, foreigners have bought a lot of our debt. So this is perhaps a hairier, more complex issue. But do you have an answer for him?

HUTCHISON: Well, I think that it's correct to say that some of this stimulus or bailout money has gone to foreign banks. Part of it AIG. And that is an area that we need to look at, where this money is going, and have more strings on it so that we assure that our financial institutions are being shored up, but also that they're getting credit out there.

You say, what are my constituents saying? My constituents are saying they cannot get credit in the marketplace.

CLAMAN: Still, after all of that?

HUTCHISON: My small businesses, my medium-size businesses cannot get credit. My auto dealers cannot get credit. It is -- that's what we've got to address. And where all of this money is going from the bailout, into foreign coffers, I think is a legitimate question, of course.

CLAMAN: Last question. Quickly, do you think Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner has a handle on this?

HUTCHISON: Well, I have to say that I don't see that he has come forward with a plan that can work. We don't see credit flowing.

I think that we made mistakes last fall, but we have not learned from those mistakes this spring. And I am very concerned that he is not on top of it, and that we have got to get a handle on the financial situation and the housing situation and stop all these stimulus packages until we correct that.

CLAMAN: Very sensible talking from you this morning, Senator. Thank you.

Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison.

HUTCHISON: Thank you, Liz.

CLAMAN: Any time.

Coming up, we have a look at "The One Thing You Should Know."

Stay tuned.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CLAMAN: And now it's time for "The One Thing You Should Know."

And that is people are still buzzing over AIG's bonus handouts. We've been getting your e-mails all morning long. We wanted to read a few more. Thank you so much for sending them.

Time to dig -- and so let's read some of these e-mails. We'll dig into the mail bag and see what everybody is talking about.

Glenn in Auburn, Alabama talks about AIG employees who are threatening to leave if they don't get their bonuses. Ah, yes. He says, "These people caused the problems! So what if they leave? Good riddance!"

PAYNE: Well, the point is, half of them are already gone.

CLAMAN: I know. They left with the money. See, they're smarter than we are.

LEE: Left with the money, yes.

Robert of Charleston, South Carolina, says, "Almost anything the government or AIG does to address the utter audacity of this scandal will be hard to trust."

So that's the next kind of chapter of this problem, right?

CLAMAN: And remember, Fox Business will be carrying that at 10:00 a.m. Eastern today, the hearing on Capitol Hill.

PAYNE: By the way, guys, ,on that trust issue, how can private funds trust the government not to limit their profits if they go into this partnership on these toxic assets, considering the uproar? Because billions are going to be made on that if it's done right.

Bill Stevens of Jamestown, North Carolina, asks, "Where was Timothy Geithner on this issue? Where was he when agreements were extended under his watch? I'll tell you what -- out to lunch -- like he is on all other economic issues."

CLAMAN: It was interesting. Did you just see Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison? She took a breath when I said does Tim Geithner have a handle on this? Granted, he's got to have a handle on a bunch of other issues, too. So it's very tough out there.

LEE: Yes, she did kind of...

PAYNE: But he's the number one guy. We need confidence in him, and obviously very few people have confidence.

CLAMAN: If he's there, you have got to have confidence in these people.

Keep the e-mails coming, folks, moneyforbreakfast @foxbusiness.com. It's very important that you e-mail us and let us know, because we are the one network who is letting your e-mails be, you know, read. And we understand how this feels.

But we've got to move this discussion forward. The dialogue has to move forward from, yes, we're totally annoyed, to what's going to happen?

LEE: And speaking of moving it forward, you have a big interview coming up on "THE CLOSING BELL" today.

CLAMAN: Mike Maroone of AutoNation. He's the president of the nation's largest auto dealer. They have a huge announcement, exclusively right here on Fox Business. It affects every single person who wants to buy any kind of car from these AutoNation dealers.

So stay tuned for that.

PAYNE: Yes. Well, I'll definitely be watching.

CLAMAN: "COUNTDOWN TO THE CLOSING BELL," 3:00 p.m. Eastern Time.

Thank you so much for joining us. We hope you have a great day.

END

urn:contentItem:7W77-4H01-2PFY-H0NR-00000-00IBM Deal; Outrage Over AIG Bonuses; Demanding Justice in AIG; February Consumer Price Index; Fox 50; Interview With Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison2009-03-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:40ZLexisNexisMONEY FOR BREAKFAST7:00 AM ESTStephen Leeb, Matt McCall, Kay Bailey Hutchison; Michele Bachmann, Gary Peters, Leslie Crocker Snyder, Jennifer Niemela, Erin Smith, Todd Spencer, Jim Roberts, Jim Gregory, Michael Dimock, Jim Himes, Shelley Moore Capito, Joe BeseckerNEWSFinancial031801cb.220IBM Deal; Outrage Over AIG Bonuses; Demanding Justice in AIG; February Consumer Price Index; Fox 50; Interview With Senator Kay Bailey HutchisonLiz Claman, Connell McShane, Charles Payne, Jenna Lee, Shibani Joshi, Gavin Grey

LIZ CLAMAN, FBN ANCHOR: Coming up this morning on MONEY FOR BREAKFAST the uproar over the AIG's bonuses races on. And lawmakers are on the move to retrieve the money.

Drug lords, kidnappings and now trade tariffs is this what we get for the $10 billion in aid the U.S. gives to Mexico? We've got a hot debate straight ahead.

And does IBM have sunny days ahead? If you're just waking up here comes the sun -- IBM wanting to buy Sun Microsystems.

We've got the latest. We're serving all that and so much more for you right here on MONEY FOR BREAKFAST.

Well, good morning everybody. Welcome to a special edition of MONEY FOR BREAKFAST. The AIG America's out outraged. I am Liz Claman. Alexis Glick is off today.

We're going to have much more on all this anger, this drama stemming from the AIG bonuses, and so much of it, we know it's coming from you.

And we actually really do want to hear from you. Are you outraged? But specifically, why? Don't just say, "Yes, I'm furious." We want to know why you're outrage and you can actually email us right here at moneyforbreakfast@foxbusiness.com and we'll actually share those with you later in the show. We'll read what some of you have to say.

But first let's get you caught up on the futures here and this after a day where we had a triple digit gain for the DOW Jones Industrial. Futures are lower today at the moment DOW Jones Industrial futures down 44 but we tend to look more at the S&P futures, they give you a better sense of what might happen with the market, they're down nearly five points; the NASDAQ down four.

Let's send it right now to Connell McShane at the Fox Business desk with the very latest. He's got earnings out from General Mills -- Connell.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: They look a little light, Liz, $3.79 a share X-items has been the number that's been reported by General Mills but the Street's looking for $0.88, so light on that front. Interesting to point out that the company says it's raising its guidance for the full year but when you look at it the guidance is still light, of where the Street estimate is. You see where the stock close yesterday $3.38 to $3.87 for the full year, $3.94 is the estimate. So the top end of the guidance at $3.87 is still light of the estimate.

General Mills among other things talking about currency translations hurting their earnings a little bit, reducing sales growth by three percentage points. The currency translation so GIS, General Mills certainly will a stock to watch today here, Liz. This one is down about 11 percent with the markets so far this year.

But the earnings look light, we'll have more on it later on the morning, right now back over to you.

CLAMAN: Yes, we'll be talking much more about General Mills because clearly you cannot ignore Count Chocolate and Boo Berry. Very important.

MCSHANE: I know it.

CLAMAN: Thank you Connell.

As I mentioned we're taking a closer look at this hour at the outrage over AIG. So let's start with the latest news, first off, Chairman and CEO of American International Group Ed Liddy pulling up a chair at a Congressional witness table today. This one is going to be so closely watched he will take massive heat. I promise you every lawmaker is going to want to make his or her voice heard very loudly, this over the more than $200 million in bonuses.

Meanwhile, Congress and the White House trying to find ways to strip bonus recipients of the money they got. Some of these people are not even with the company anymore and they we're getting millions and million of dollars worth.

The chairman of ranking member of the Senate Finance Committee proposed companies and individuals pay a 35 percent tax on all retention awards and bonuses over $50,000.

And in a letter to Congress, Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner suggesting holding back the bonus amount from upcoming bailout funds for AIG.

There are all kinds of ideas being thrown out here on how to get the money back but do you have ideas, I mean, how angry are you over this bonus debacle? If you are steamed, you're not alone we're not just talking about lawmakers.

Fox Business's senior Washington correspondent, Peter Barnes is in our Washington Bureau with the results -- Peter a new Pew Research Center Poll, boy they gets these things out pretty quickly, what do we see?

PETER BARNES, FBN SENIOR WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: Well that's right, Liz, the AIG bonus controversy a possible big political headache for President Obama if the financial bailout doesn't work and if he has to go back to Congress later for more money to help banks.

The White House continuing to express outrage about the bonuses, distancing itself from the controversy and trying to get out in front of the story that was inevitably going to dominate the headlines anyway.

But the President remains fully vested in a bank rescue plan, he voted for it as a Senator. And as President he says it is critical to reviving bank lending and the economy.

On Monday, the Pew Research Center released the poll that found that 87 percent of people are outright angry about or at least bothered by bank bailouts.

In the poll, despite their anger, people still supported bank rescues as a policy 48 percent to 40 percent. But the poll was taken last week before revelations of the AIG bonuses.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MICHAEL DIMOCK, PEW RESEARCH CENTER: I think if anything this has intensified the emotional feeling that people have. Again, they've been giving a clear example of the downside of this policy the problems with the way that this money is being spent. I think that intensifies the anger now. Whether it's going to undermine the support for the policy, it's something that we're going to need to see how it plays out.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARNES: Now, the President has to be somewhat careful on how he plays the AIG bonus controversy, Dimock says. His job approval rating is starting to slip. The PEW poll shows it down five points from February to March, Dimock says mainly over public concern about his stimulus plan, his budget and how they will increase the deficit as well as some concern over his foreign policy.

But the President did include a $750 billion placeholder in his budget for more funding for bank bailouts if he needs it. Being outraged about how AIG now may leave the President in a delicate political position, later with Congress and voters trying to turn a negative consequence of the bailout, taxpayer money going to big bonuses into a positive, cleaning up the system by continuing those very bailouts.

Liz, back to you.

CLAMAN: There is no way Peter, anybody is going rubber-stamp more spending with these AIG bonuses unless this gets resolved. Unbelievable. Thanks for the PEW Research Center.

BARNES: No way, you're right.

CLAMAN: Yes, here take my money.

BARNES: Yes.

CLAMAN: The AIG bonus was the talk of the halls on Capitol Hill yesterday. Massachusetts Congressman and Chairman of the House Financial Services Committee Barney Frank was confounded by Ed Liddy of AIG's reasoning for payment of the bonuses. Listen in.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. BARNEY FRANK, CHAIRMAN OF THE HOUSE FINANCIAL SERVICES COMMITTEE: Mr. Liddy gave two arguments. One, was my hands are tied legally but the other was a policy argument. He doesn't want to rescind them because he wants to retain those people. I am very skeptical that retaining the people who made the mistakes is a good idea.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CLAMAN: For more on today's hearings and this outrage that we know so many of you are feeling, I am joined now by Democratic Congressman Jim Himes of Connecticut and Republican Congresswoman Shelley Moore Capito of West Virginia. Both served on the House Financial Services Committee.

Well, did you bring your boxing gloves? Both of you, I can only imagine...

REP. JIM HIMES (D), CONNECTICUT: Good morning Liz.

CLAMAN: Ed Liddy sitting in front of you. I will start with the Representative Himes. Give me a sense of what you want and need to hear from Ed Liddy today.

HIMES: Well, you know, as you pointed out in your story the outrage is out there is unbelievable. And you know, Congress represents the people and so I think you are going to see some outrage today.

But you know I had the opportunity to sit with Mr. Liddy in my office yesterday. And what I told him was, it's not just important that the right thing happens but that the right thing be seen to happen.

So I said, you know look, my experience is that 10 very smart lawyers in the room can make just about anything happen so please get 10 lawyers in the room and figure out how to fix this.

And if you can't do that, get these 73 people that are receiving these bonuses together in a conference room and say folks, this is the time to stand up and do the right thing for your country.

Give back the money. Because if those two things don't happen, action will be taken either in the halls of Congress or by the State of Connecticut where this particular unit is resident. And it's really important that they step up and do the right thing not just so that the many people who have lost their jobs out there see that everybody is in this together but because as you point out, we are not through stabilizing the financial sector yet.

We've got work yet to do and every time something like this happens our hands get tied.

CLAMAN: Representative Moore Capito, Ed Liddy has an op-ed piece in the "Washington Post" today and in it one of the lines that caught my eye was where he said, "In America when we owe people money we pay them, ok." So I think that's not nod to the hall if there is a contract you can't break it in America we get that.

We understand that but Representative Himes, just said, get a couple of lawyers into the room. We can figure something out here.

Congress has suggested taxing these bonuses up to 95 percent and Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner says that he's working on this as well but what is your solution? What do you and your brethren in Congress feel about this?

SHELLEY MOORE CAPITO (R), WEST VIRGINIA: Well, I think we recognize with all of the different programs and policies that are coming forward, that just this morning as I was coming in the guard said to me something isn't right. And we need to make this situation to a point where people understand what's going on but still reflecting the outrage and the astonishment of the lack of transparency and the lack of accountability.

My question to Mr. Liddy will be you knew these were part of the contract, you knew in good faith and bargaining good faith with the United States government why were these questions not answered?

Where is the transparency and accountability of the tax dollars? Why did AIG not come forward and if they did, why did the Treasury accept this as part of the agreement to further fund and to further bailout this company?

CLAMAN: I am glad you brought up the Treasury Secretary. Representative Himes, we talked about what Treasury Secretary Geithner wants to do and he says, "We will impose on AIG in essence a contractual commitment to pay the Treasury from the operations of the company the amount of retention awards just paid. In addition we will deduct the $30 billion -- deduct from there in assistance an amount basically equal to the amount of those payments." What does that really mean? And is that the solution?

HIMES: Well, what that really means is that our taxpayer dollars are not going to pay bonuses for people who are not just involved but remember these are folks that were in the unit of AIG that created the credit defaults swap exposure that brought the company down.

And so I think as a matter of principle the notion that our hard earned taxpayer dollars aren't going to provide bonuses to those people is a pretty good notion. Now, the Treasury affect debt maybe Congressional legislation could affect that but frankly, as I said before I'd like to see AIG stand up and do the right thing here, either by getting those people together to agree to give back the money or to figure out a way to get around those contracts.

And this notion that you can't get around the contract look, all over this country, firefighters, policeman, teachers are being asked to reopen their contracts to give back wages and benefits. So I don't think it's crazy to say that we ought to take a look at that here.

CLAMAN: It's not. Representative Moore Capito, but the argument out there also floating around on Wall Street, well, you take away their bonuses and you're not going to find anybody to these jobs. Do you buy that?

MOORE CAPITO: Well, I inherently disagree with that, I mean, I think that you are looking at large financial institutions that were brought to their knees by basically a lot of greed and over extension of risk.

And to think that the American spirit and as the young good minds in this country, would not want to bring these companies back without, you know, extravagant bonuses, without holding the taxpayer out for more and more dollars. I think that's a ridiculous concept. I don't buy that.

And I think that the fact that I agree with Jim when he says there are people all over this country that are taking pay cuts, that are working for less times, that are losing their jobs, that are making adjustments in their families and why these employees at AIG and others can not tighten their belts and make adjustments too or break a contract is just doesn't pass the snip test.

CLAMAN: Representative Himes, you're out there in Connecticut where most of your constituents and many of them and certainly are hedge fund people or financial people but you're also looking at constituents who are looking specifically at Congress and saying, so many members, many of actually the sub-Committee members have taken money from AIG in the form of donations.

How do you answer to that?

HIMES: Well, you know the overall campaign finance system is a broken system and I think you'd find general agreement on that in Congress.

But look, you raised another very broader and an important point which is that as the stones get thrown today and rightly so, Congress is not blame free here. The product -- the credit defaults swaps that are at the heart of AIG's mess were explicitly unregulated by an act of Congress a number of years ago.

So while this will be a day of popular expression of anger at AIG we need to not forget that to some degree Congress was complicit in the mess that grew up at AIG. And we need to look forward and say, look, we need a smart set of regulations, not necessarily more regulations, but smart regulations that are going to prevent this from happening ever again. That's our job. And we've got to step up to do it.

CLAMAN: Well, the party starts at 10:00 a.m. Eastern time. I mean, this is going to be interesting. Fox Business will be carrying these grilling of Ed Liddy. Congress Member Jim Himes and Shelley Moore Capito, thank you both for joining us.

MOORE CAPITO: Thank you.

HIMES: Thank you.

CLAMAN: Anytime. We really appreciate your perspective

And out there, you guys, we want to hear what you think about what is going on with AIG and certainly how this event in Congress is going to developer. Send us an e-mail at moneyforbreakfast@foxbusiness.com

Get up out of bed. Fire up the computer; share some of your thoughts with us. We're actually going to be reading some of them coming up.

We do have a lot of market news here. General Mills reporting earnings this morning and giving full year forecast. You may be eating some of their food for breakfast. What's the breakdown in store for the cereal maker?

But first, let the sun shine in. That's what IBM is saying as a massive computer deal may be in the offing -- the biggest deal possibly that IBM has ever made?

Good morning to you. That's a big news story coming up. We are back in two minutes.

MCSHANE: Connell McShane back on MONEY FOR BREAKFAST with some breaking news out of the "Wall Street Journal" this morning with an interesting report that IBM might be in the market to buy Sun Microsystems and pay $6.5 billion in cash to do so which would be, give or take, a 100 percent premium over the close for Sun yesterday.

Now let's take a look at the stock prices involved. You would expect that Sun Microsystems would be higher and it is. There is IBM down about two or three percent in the pre-market; as you see, the bid's 90.25 and the stock had closed just under 93 yesterday. Sun, ticker simple JAVA, these days is up to $8.10. So that's a 60 percent move, give or take, on the stock so being bid up on the "Wall Street Journal" report again that these two are in talks, Liz, about a possible deal. That'll be very, very interesting.

CLAMAN: Maybe making that deal. Wouldn't that be interesting to see?

MCSHANE: That would be up.

CLAMAN: Thank you very much, Connell. For more on this possible deal between IBM and Sun Microsystems I'm joined by Emerald Asset Management's Joe Besecker, and president of Penn Financial Group, Matt McCall.

Joe, you wake up and you find out...

JOE BESECKER, EMERALD ASSET MANAGEMENT: A jab, a jolt.

CLAMAN: The jab, a jolt. Seriously? IBM the sleepy -- not sleepy but the more serious sort of button-down company going for the mavericky so to speak?

(CROSS TALK)

BESECKER: I just like the fact that business is being done out there. We're back to doing business.

CLAMAN: Thank you.

BESECKER: We're not talking about -- listen, that's the thing. IBM is taking advantage of opportunities that exist out there. You know, Mark Twain once said he was rarely able to spot an opportunity until it ceased to be one. And so, maybe now the companies will start to pay -- get out from under their desks, start to look for business and do business. And that's what I'm excited about.

Whether or not this is the best deal for IBM or maybe the market's (ph) thing and maybe they could have gotten it a little bit cheaper?

CLAMAN: Exactly that. I'm wondering, are they overpaying in this market? Aren't you supposed to beat somebody down to their last dollar?

MATT MCCALL, PRESIDENT, PENN FINANCIAL GROUP: You are but you figure, Sun already fell 71 percent in the last year. So maybe it has been beaten down already paying at $10 a share, whatever it may be $6.5 billion. I don't think that is that bad. I actually think they are getting a pretty good deal.

And what I love about this is the synergy that it creates between the two companies. But I think we're going to see a lot more mergers going on in the coming months that creates synergies and using...

BESECKER: I hope so.

MCCALL: ...and using its beaten down prices and as Joe said this is a good sign, I think, for the market.

CLAMAN: Both make corporate systems. And I think that that's something that these corporations who don't depend specifically on Microsoft Windows, for example, are very interested in seeing who gets nervous over this. Is it Hewlett-Packard, the big competitor?

BESECKER: Go back to what I'm saying. Now it puts us in a position where people start to think strategically about business again. How do we deploy money? How do we go out and do things?

So yes, I think Hewlett-Packard has to be concerned about this. I think in general, IBM does a lot of service business. I think this will add to the service. And they penetrate different areas they may not have had.

It appears to get customers and get customers cheaply and that's what they're doing because that customer base is an annuity that brings all that money in. Oracle reports today or tomorrow, that is the only thing that's going to go well for them. And so you want to have growth as well and I think they'll get a growth opportunity...

CLAMAN: Sources, by the way, say this, of course, could still fall apart. So we caution people to make sure they understand that but what about regulatory hurdles, Matt? These are two gigantic companies that could eliminate some of the little guys out there.

MCCALL: And it probably will. The thing is though, Sun has lost a lot of market share over the last couple of years. So I think they'll be able to get through the hurdles.

And I think HP gets hurt the most because when you think about it HP actually had a chance to buy Sun. In the last year they went to them and they turned them down and now IBM is jumping on that after the price fell a bit more. So I think IBM is being pro-active here looking forward or HP's kind of sitting back waiting for the business to come to them.

CLAMAN: What is the best possible sense that you make specifically I think for other suitors? Anybody -- you know Matt has talked about Hewlett-Packard. They're not going to come back maybe and start fighting, would they?

BESECKER: Why wouldn't they? I mean if they really thought -- depending on price. I think that is why the price is what it is. We don't know the price because it has not been announced. We just hear rumors. But if the price is there, I think that's one of the reasons that they came out with a good best offer.

CLAMAN: I'm with Joe Besecker right now because I'd look at this and I say we have some deals going.

BESECKER: Exactly.

CLAMAN: So what is the next digital deal that might be done?

MCCALL: You know, I'm actually going to go away from digital because I don't know if it is going to be as much in technology. I think the more deals are going to be in biotech. MCCALL: I think they're going to feel -- going to the food, I mean, we all go to the grocery store every day. And when we see how the prices - - they have not come down.

Even though this economy has come down, our wages have come down, prices at the grocery store have not come down. Maybe we're buying the private label versus the brand name; however, those prices are still high. And once we see wheat prices, corn prices start picking back up again, as you spoke of earlier with the commodity prices, we're going to see even higher prices for the consumer.

CLAMAN: By the way, we got General Mills' numbers earlier this morning, and they actually missed estimates. But interestingly enough, they upped their full-year guidance, and commodity prices are down. They're still managing to make money. Something tells me that when they hiked those cereal prices -- remember that?

LEEB: Yes.

CLAMAN: ... or they made the boxes smaller but kept the price the same, they still have pricing power.

LEEB: Liz, what you have to understand, there are 2.3 billion people in China and India. These economies are still growing. So are the Middle Eastern economies.

At least half the world is still growing. And that half is the world that needs commodities in order to grow. They need evermore commodities.

In this country, we can grow without using additional commodities. Europe can grow without using additional commodities. But the engine of this world need commodities in order to grow.

MCCALL: And as the middle class grows, more food.

LEEB: Everything more. Moving up the food chain.

CLAMAN: I'm not hearing either of you say buy equities. You're not saying that now.

LEEB: Well, I think buy selected equities.

CLAMAN: That are related to commodities?

LEEB: Well, that are related to inflation. I mean, you know, growth stocks that -- I think, you know, basically any company that came through 2008, which I think is kind of a microcosm for what to expect over the next five to 10 years, inflation, deflation, et cetera, is probably a good buy. Stocks like TEVA, for example, stocks like CVS.

CLAMAN: Do you own those?

LEEB: Yes.

CLAMAN: What about you?

MCCALL: I do. I like stocks here, but you have to be a stock picker. But I think the two areas that I'm looking at, one is market turns, emerging markets and commodities, both based on this commodity inflation play.

CLAMAN: Stephen, Matt, thanks to both of you.

LEEB: Thanks, Liz.

CLAMAN: They're liking gold right now. What can I say? And copper.

Let me guess, you like palladium, too?

LEEB: Yes!

CLAMAN: I knew he liked palladium!

LEEB: And platinum.

CLAMAN: Nickel and zinc as well.

LEEB: We're compatriots. I didn't know him the first time I met you.

(LAUGHTER)

CLAMAN: Coming up, we'll see if Apple's big iPhone update gave its stock a big boost with a look at the Fox 50.

And then in 90 seconds, Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison of Texas joining me live to talk about the growing outrage from lawmakers in Washington over the bonuses handed out by AIG. And what about her colleagues who took money from the troubled insurer?

A lot of answering that we are expecting here, but stay tuned. We've got much more than that on MONEY FOR BREAKFAST.

We'll be right back.

PAYNE: The Fox 50 returning to its winning ways yesterday. Our index gained 17 points to close at 584.

This morning, there is word of a posible merger in the index. IBM could buy Sun Microsystems.

For more, I'm joined by Matt McCall, the president of Penn Financial Group.

Let's start with Apple real quick, though.

The stock was up big time yesterday. It had been floating around. It looks like it's on the cusp of a major breakout through $100. Is it all about updating their software or is there more to it?

MCCALL: I think there's more to it. I mean, updating the software, the good news always gives Apple, you know, a bit of a bounce. People love hearing the new products coming out.

However, I think Apple is just a value at this level. If you're looking for growth plays, looking for something to play off the consumer turning around, Apple's the best play. I own the stock and think it's a great long-term...

(CROSSTALK)

PAYNE: You got a target on it?

MCCALL: You know, I'm looking at about $120 is the next couple of months. If it breaks through -- like you just said, if it gets through that $100 level, it's going to take off. But it's been struggling there over the last few weeks.

PAYNE: IBM in the news in "The Wall Street Journal" this morning, perhaps buying Sun Micro $6.5 billion. Do you like the deal? IBM just down a little bit on that news.

MCCALL: I think it's a good deal. I think they're picking up on cheap -- I mean, Sun's down 71 percent over the last 12 months. Even though you're paying 100 percent premium, I think it's a nice play.

And you look at IBM stock over the last couple of years, it's one of the few big tech stocks that's held up very well. So it's one of those -- you know, the grandmother stock. Your grandmother can buy IBM and throw it in her basket.

PAYNE: Do you own any?

MCCALL: I do own some IBM, yes.

PAYNE: Really? Good. Good.

All right. We've got to talk about Coca-Cola. This is really interesting.

We've seen some saber rattling out of China with respect to holding out treasuries. We think something is going on here behind the scenes. Now they're rejecting a possible takeover of Coke, one of their largest fruit juice companies, $2.4 billion bid for high-end juice.

What do you make of this and what's the impact going to be on IBM?

MCCALL: I think eventually it's going to get through. I think this deal will eventually get through. Maybe not this company...

PAYNE: IBM's already said though -- I think they've said already this morning that they're not going to pursue it any more. I'm sorry, Coke.

MCCALL: Coke.

PAYNE: Obviously IBM's not going to pursue it.

MCCALL: They'll take a different angle. I think they want to get in China. They know the growth potential in China. They're going to get over there.

The one concern though with Coke, in looking at the way the stock has performed recently, it's gotten hit because of the dollar. I mean, the dollar has risen, and they're such a global company, but I think the U.S. dollar is going to fall in the next, let's say, 12 to 18 months. So this is a play on the falling U.S. dollar, it is a play on growth.

But as a stock, I don't know. And I think there's a lot more exciting plays out there right now.

PAYNE: Well, let's talk about something that's been really exciting recently, Bank of America. The chairman, he's really been on the offensive here recently. Now talking about possibly paying back TARP money this year.

A, do you believe him? And B, could this help the stock? It was edging up before we came on air. It was edging just a little bit higher.

MCCALL: I mean, how can you believe him? I mean, honestly, I don't believe a word out of anybody's mouth from Wall Street to the White House anymore. I think (INAUDIBLE) research. Buying Bank of America here, it's like throwing a dart. I mean, it's probably going to be one to make it out.

I'm much prefer...

PAYNE: You just said you want excitement. This is exciting.

MCCALL: It's exciting, but I also want to get some sleep at night as well. So I don't like it here. I like J.P. Morgan, Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley. Those are the three that I'd be looking at. Not as exciting as a Bank of America or Citigroup, but a much better risk reward play.

PAYNE: Right, less risk. And...

MCCALL: And the reward is still high. I mean, I think you have a lot of upside on all three of those stocks.

PAYNE: Thanks a lot, Matt. Really appreciate it.

MCCALL: Thanks, Charles.

(NEWSBREAK)

CLAMAN: Lawmakers are up in arms over the $165 million bonuses handed out to American International Group. And the head of the Senate Banking Committee, Chris Dodd of Connecticut, says he supports his colleagues' calls to recoup the taxpayer funds.

Dodd, though, has received nearly $300,000 over 20 years from the failed insurer. And folks, you know what? He's not alone. The list is legion, including both Republicans and Democrats who took money from AIG.

But here now to weigh in on the topic, Republican Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison of Texas.

Welcome, Senator. Thank you for joining us.

SEN. KAY BAILEY HUTCHISON (R), TEXAS: Thank you, liz.

CLAMAN: Well, let me ask you, first, did you take any money from AIG in campaign contributions?

HUTCHISON: Liz, I don't know. I'm so sorry. I don't know. I have not even looked at my contribution list with regard to that.

CLAMAN: It's never come up? Really?

HUTCHISON: I have a very firm opinion about these bonuses.

CLAMAN: Yes.

HUTCHISON: You know, regardless of whether I have -- and we can certainly check that -- I think that what the executives are doing is outrageous. I think retention bonuses for people who have already left is just not acceptable to the American people.

CLAMAN: I'm sure, because it's become such a hot-button issue here. We have received this morning alone hundreds and hundreds of e-mails.

What are your constituents telling you, Senator?

HUTCHISON: Oh, they're outraged. They're outraged by all of the big spending that scares people to death with the debt that we have and the deficits that we are accumulating.

They are outraged by these bailouts. Some are to big to fail, some are not. The bailout mania, I think, has just gone out of control, and that's what I'm hearing from my constituents.

And you know, Liz, there is more of a fear factor than I've known in my lifetime right now, because they see the problem, but they don't see a solution that is going to work. And that's what I'm hearing.

CLAMAN: These bonuses have everybody so riled up, Senator, as you know. But are we missing the bigger picture? And that is that when the TARP was pushed through initially, it just wasn't put in place where there were handcuffs that would prevent this kind of thing from happening, even though people demanded it.

Did Congress members read this closely enough? Why didn't they ensure that something would be put in that would prevent us down the road from facing this angst and anger?

HUTCHISON: I think that is a very legitimate criticism. I do.

Originally, Secretary Paulson asked for no strings at all, wanted $700 billion, and said that the global economy was going to crash if we didn't do it.

CLAMAN: I remember.

HUTCHISON: We didn't give him a no-strings-attached opening of the Treasury. We cut it to $350 billion.

We did put parameters around it. But clearly, we did not foresee all of the things that these people would do, like take trips, like give bonuses. We just thought that there would be a factor where all of these executives would come together like Americans come together to solve problems, and that they would do the right thing.

That was a mistaken assumption. However, now, Liz, we are not learning from that mistake, and we are continuing to throw money at problems without the necessary restraint and parameters put around it.

CLAMAN: Sure. Are you, Senator -- are you of the belief we can't let AIG go down because something horrible will happen?

HUTCHISON: Well, as I understand it, AIG has such a global impact because it is an insurer of last resort in so many areas. And that's why the original AIG bailout came from the Treasury, because Mr. Bernanke saw that as well.

Now we actually have put 80 percent of the company's capital on the line from American taxpayers, and I just think we've got to take a stronger control here. And we can't own 80 percent of a company and have executives taking bonuses for retention when they've already left.

CLAMAN: Do you think...

HUTCHISON: Let me say, too, Liz, I think you all talked about this earlier today. The contracts have already been breached. So to say this is a contractual obligation, when they have not met the performance standards that are in the contract, I think does bring into question that we would have the power to do more.

CLAMAN: I'm absolutely with you on that. A contract, I absolutely believe, should be held up. But when the other side doesn't deliver what they promised, that's a problem.

An opinion article in "The Wall Street Journal" yesterday said this: "The politicians prefer to talk about AIG's latest bonus payments because they deflect attention from Washington's failure to supervise AIG."

How do you respond to that, Senator?

HUTCHISON: I think it's valid. I think that the regulatory reform that is needed for AIG and for our financial institutions, and for the institutions that are doing all of these fancy derivatives that have been virtually unregulated, must be regulated in a responsible way. We don't want to go overboard, but we certainly know where the vacancies are in our regulatory system today, and we need to address that.

CLAMAN: Senator, one of your constituents just shot us an e-mail, wanted to get it to you. Neil Lewis in Granbury, Texas, says, "Why are we outraged at the bonuses when we are supporting foreign banks to the tunes of tens of billions of dollars?"

Now, just to clarify, foreigners have bought a lot of our debt. So this is perhaps a hairier, more complex issue. But do you have an answer for him?

HUTCHISON: Well, I think that it's correct to say that some of this stimulus or bailout money has gone to foreign banks. Part of it AIG. And that is an area that we need to look at, where this money is going, and have more strings on it so that we assure that our financial institutions are being shored up, but also that they're getting credit out there.

You say, what are my constituents saying? My constituents are saying they cannot get credit in the marketplace.

CLAMAN: Still, after all of that?

HUTCHISON: My small businesses, my medium-size businesses cannot get credit. My auto dealers cannot get credit. It is -- that's what we've got to address. And where all of this money is going from the bailout, into foreign coffers, I think is a legitimate question, of course.

CLAMAN: Last question. Quickly, do you think Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner has a handle on this?

HUTCHISON: Well, I have to say that I don't see that he has come forward with a plan that can work. We don't see credit flowing.

I think that we made mistakes last fall, but we have not learned from those mistakes this spring. And I am very concerned that he is not on top of it, and that we have got to get a handle on the financial situation and the housing situation and stop all these stimulus packages until we correct that.

CLAMAN: Very sensible talking from you this morning, Senator. Thank you.

Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison.

HUTCHISON: Thank you, Liz.

CLAMAN: Any time.

Coming up, we have a look at "The One Thing You Should Know."

Stay tuned.

CLAMAN: And now it's time for "The One Thing You Should Know."

And that is people are still buzzing over AIG's bonus handouts. We've been getting your e-mails all morning long. We wanted to read a few more. Thank you so much for sending them.

Time to dig -- and so let's read some of these e-mails. We'll dig into the mail bag and see what everybody is talking about.

Glenn in Auburn, Alabama talks about AIG employees who are threatening to leave if they don't get their bonuses. Ah, yes. He says, "These people caused the problems! So what if they leave? Good riddance!"

PAYNE: Well, the point is, half of them are already gone.

CLAMAN: I know. They left with the money. See, they're smarter than we are.

LEE: Left with the money, yes.

Robert of Charleston, South Carolina, says, "Almost anything the government or AIG does to address the utter audacity of this scandal will be hard to trust."

So that's the next kind of chapter of this problem, right?

CLAMAN: And remember, Fox Business will be carrying that at 10:00 a.m. Eastern today, the hearing on Capitol Hill.

PAYNE: By the way, guys, ,on that trust issue, how can private funds trust the government not to limit their profits if they go into this partnership on these toxic assets, considering the uproar? Because billions are going to be made on that if it's done right.

Bill Stevens of Jamestown, North Carolina, asks, "Where was Timothy Geithner on this issue? Where was he when agreements were extended under his watch? I'll tell you what -- out to lunch -- like he is on all other economic issues."

CLAMAN: It was interesting. Did you just see Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison? She took a breath when I said does Tim Geithner have a handle on this? Granted, he's got to have a handle on a bunch of other issues, too. So it's very tough out there.

LEE: Yes, she did kind of...

PAYNE: But he's the number one guy. We need confidence in him, and obviously very few people have confidence.

CLAMAN: If he's there, you have got to have confidence in these people.

Keep the e-mails coming, folks, moneyforbreakfast @foxbusiness.com. It's very important that you e-mail us and let us know, because we are the one network who is letting your e-mails be, you know, read. And we understand how this feels.

But we've got to move this discussion forward. The dialogue has to move forward from, yes, we're totally annoyed, to what's going to happen?

LEE: And speaking of moving it forward, you have a big interview coming up on "THE CLOSING BELL" today.

CLAMAN: Mike Maroone of AutoNation. He's the president of the nation's largest auto dealer. They have a huge announcement, exclusively right here on Fox Business. It affects every single person who wants to buy any kind of car from these AutoNation dealers.

So stay tuned for that.

PAYNE: Yes. Well, I'll definitely be watching.

CLAMAN: "COUNTDOWN TO THE CLOSING BELL," 3:00 p.m. Eastern Time.

Thank you so much for joining us. We hope you have a great day.

Updated 3:18 p.m. ET with IBM comment.

By Matt EganNEW YORK (CNNMoney)

NEW YORK (CNNMoney) -- The SEC is investigating IBM.

IBM said on Tuesday that the SEC is conducting an investigation related to the company's accounting treatment of certain transactions in the U.S., U.K. and Ireland.

IBM said in a regulatory filing it learned of the probe in August and is cooperating with the government agency.

It's not clear precisely what the SEC is investigating. IBM did not specify beyond saying it relates to "revenue recognition."

"IBM has a rigorous and disciplined process for the preparation of its financial statements and the reporting of revenue," IBM said in a statement to CNNMoney.

The SEC declined to comment.

IBM shares fell 3% following the disclosure of the investigation. The company's stock is down 14% over the past year amid slumping hardware sales and the stronger U.S. dollar. Earlier in the day the company rewarded shareholders with a $4 billion increase to its share buyback program.

In the past big tech companies have landed in hot water with European regulators for taking advantage of Ireland's relatively low tax rates. For example, Google and Apple have been accused of shifting profits between international subsidiaries to dodge taxes.

Last fall Ireland announced plans to close the tax loophole for tech giants. Apple said earlier this year it could be forced to pay a decade's worth of back taxes to Ireland.

urn:contentItem:5Y4K-H5H1-JC85-N4BB-00000-00IBM, Marriott and Mickey Mouse Take On Tech's Favorite Law2020-02-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:40ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYIBM, Marriott and Mickey Mouse Take On Tech's Favorite LawDavid McCabe

A motley group of powerful companies have their knives out for Section 230, which shields platforms from lawsuits over content posted by users.

WASHINGTON - Disney and its powerful trade association have fought to stop the law's spread abroad.

Marriott has asked Congress to amend the law.

IBM has a plan to slim it down.

An unusual constellation of powerful companies and industries are fighting to weaken Big Tech by limiting the reach of one of its most sacred laws. The law, known as Section 230, makes it nearly impossible to sue platforms like Facebook or Google for the words, images and videos posted by their users.

The companies' motivations vary somewhat. Hollywood is concerned about copyright abuse, especially abroad, while Marriott would like to make it harder for Airbnb to fight local hotel laws. IBM wants consumer online services to be more responsible for the content on their sites.

But they all see an opening as both Democrats and Republicans increasingly raise their own concerns about the power of the tech industry and the law. Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act of 1996 has helped Facebook, Google and YouTube grow into giants by holding only the people who post the billions of pieces of content on their services responsible for libel or other legal issues.

Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said in a recent interview that Section 230 should be immediately "revoked." Senators Lindsey Graham, a South Carolina Republican, and Brian Schatz, a Hawaii Democrat, are drafting bills that could increase the tech companies' liability. The Justice Department is conducting a review of the law.

"People are either mad at tech companies and, legitimately in some cases, want to constrain their power for a lot of reasons," said Daphne Keller, a professor at Stanford Law School who used to be a lawyer for Google. "Or companies are competing with tech companies and want to constrain their power for competitive reasons.

"And a lot of those reasons are really complicated, but the easiest lever to hurt tech companiesthat a lot of people see is 230."

So far, the companies critical of the law have had mixed success with their lobbying. In 2018, Congress gave victims and prosecutors more power to sue websites that knowingly aided sex trafficking. The law passed with support from companies like Disney, Oracle and IBM.

But the recent trade pact with Canada and Mexico contained Section 230-like protections, potentially locking in tech-friendly rules abroad.

Now critics of Section 230 are focused on pushing to keep similar language out of future trade pacts. A handout distributed by Disney's lobbyists last year warned Congress that trade deals with the provision would make it difficult for Congress to change the law in a way that improved the internet.

"On an almost weekly basis," the handout said, "additional concerns are being raised: illegal opioid sales, spread of terrorist propaganda, foreign government election meddling, spread of material and tools that help pedophiles connect."

Companies like Google and Facebook say that without Section 230 protections, building a business that gives individuals a platform for their content online would be impossible. They say it also shields online platforms from lawsuits when they police criminal or distasteful content.

Silicon Valley can employ significant resources to make its case. Google and Facebook spend millions a year on federal lobbying and are regular donors to outside policy groups. Their allies on Capitol Hill, like Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, have defended the law.

Michael Beckerman, the president of the Internet Association, an industry group whose members include Google and Facebook, said Section 230 was "foundational to almost everything people do online."

"It enables products and services that consumers love and rely upon every day," Mr. Beckerman said in a statement.

While criticism of Section 230 had mounted for years, the coalition of corporate interests questioning the value of the protections took root in late 2017 when Disney and 21st Century Fox backed the bill allowing lawsuits against web platforms for knowingly facilitating sex trafficking.

"I had never seen them getting involved in any Section 230 issues before," said Jeff Kosseff, a lawyer who wrote a book about the law.

Now, hotel companies worry about Airbnb's use of Section 230 in lawsuits seeking to block local ordinances regulating home-sharing platforms. Judges have ruled against the company in many of those cases.

The Washington lobbying group that represents companies like Marriott, Hilton and Hyatt has backed a bill that would amend Section 230 so it didn't apply to home-rental services in many cases.

Airbnb declined to comment.

IBM, which like other enterprise software providers is trying to distance itself from businesses like Facebook, has supported adjusting Section 230 so that companies must take "reasonable care" to keep unlawful uses of their platforms in check. The proposal would apply to companies that not only hosted information but also made it available to the public. That means it would cover a consumer service like Instagram but not to a cloud computing provider like IBM.

The Motion Picture Association and the News Media Alliance, a group that lobbies for news organizations, have urged the Trump administration not to allow the protections in a future trade deal with Britain. The film group's concern is that it could make copyright enforcement more difficult. (The New York Times is a member of the News Media Alliance.)

Many of the consumer groups that have been critical of Section 230 don't share the companies' motivations. But they welcome the help from the companies, which have vast lobbying networks and the ability to get a meeting with the right aide at just the right time.

Gretchen Peters, who leads the Alliance to Counter Crime Online, a group critical of Section 230, said her small organization was spread thin. If "somebody else, like the Disney folks or the hotel folks," set up a meeting, she said, "I'll come along."

urn:contentItem:518H-PF71-JCMB-G2N0-00000-00IBM On Deck: Expect Steady Growth2010-10-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:40ZLexisNexisPERSONAL FINANCEStock StrategiesIBM On Deck: Expect Steady GrowthJames RogersStaff Reporter

NEW YORK (TheStreet) -- Though IBM is the less flashy of the two big tech firms reporting quarterly earnings after the bell Monday -- Appleis the other -- investors can expect more of what the lumbering giant has come to represent: Slow, steady growth. Last quarter, IBM   missed revenue targets and reported a 12% decline in its services sector revenue, due in part to the faltering economy and its battle with big currency headwinds.

Analysts are cautiously bullish for IBM's third-quarter results, heralding the uptick in corporate spending that Intelalluded to last week. "I expect that IBM's services group has benefitted from this uptick and the company has wisely been offering a lot of deals to spur renewals and new business," said Laura DiDio, principal with research firm ITIC, in an e-mail to TheStreet.Accenturehas also raised expectations for IBM's vast services business. The consulting giant and IBM rival recently reported strong fourth-quarter results, boosted by $6.5 billion worth of new bookings. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters expect IBM to report quarterly EPS of $2.75 on revenue of $24.13 billion, up from $2.40 on sales of $23.57 billion the company reported in the year-ago period. Analysts are also hoping to see evidence of top-line sales growth, but only at a rate of about 3%. "We think IBM had a reasonable, though far from spectacular, September quarter," wrote BMO Capital Markets analyst Keith Bachman in a recent note. Bachman holds an outperform on the stock. "As we look to the December quarter, we believe IBM will have improving growth rates in hardware and the potential for better growth rates in services. Hence, we think IBM can be a good Q4 stock." Investors will be eager to get an update on IBM's M&A strategy when the tech giant discusses its results. One of tech's biggest predators, IBM shows no signs of slowing down on its acquisition tear, as evidenced by its recent   purchases of privately-heldPSS Systems and   Blade Network Technologies, as well as its   $1.7 billion deal for data warehousing specialistNetezza. In the business analytics space alone, IBM has spent more than $12 billion in the last five years, acquiring some 23 companies. Charles King, an analyst at tech research firm Pund-IT, told TheStreet that he expects to see IBM focus future M&A on making servers and storage run more efficiently. "The workload optimization channel is one that IBM and other vendors are headed down one way or the other," he said. "And IBM is being far more proactive [on that front] than Oracleor HP." King is also keen to see IBM push the M&A envelope into   less obvious areas. "We're in such a phase of intense industry consolidation right now that if a good, intriguing very innovative hardware company came up for sale, it wouldn't surprise me if IBM reached into its pocket and went for it," he said. Security specialists Blue Coat Systemsand Websensehave already been touted as   attractive potential targets. There has also been chatter linking IBM to   Israeli networking specialistRadware.The tech bellwether, however, recently warned that its acquisition strategy and organic growth could be   impacted by increased regulation of the derivatives market.In midday trading Monday, IBM was up 92 cents to $141.98. --Written by James Rogers in New York, with additional reporting by Maggie Overfelt.>To follow the writers on Twitter, go to   http://twitter.com/jamesjrogers and   http://twitter.com/maggieoverfelt.>To submit a news tip, send an email to:   tips@thestreet.com.

urn:contentItem:5XXJ-HG81-F11P-X319-00000-00IBM opens data centres in UAE to help rev up enterprises' journey to hybrid cloud2020-01-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:40ZLexisNexisIBM opens data centres in UAE to help rev up enterprises' journey to hybrid cloudNaushad K. Cherrayil

Sees huge growth opportunity as 80% of workloads still sit on on-premises

IBM has joined the bandwagon to open data centres in the UAE – Dubai and Abu Dhabi - to provide managed services to enterprises and help accelerate their journey to the hybrid cloud.

Big tech companies have shown interest in the Middle East, especially in the UAE, to open data centres. Amazon Web Services has a cluster of data centres in Bahrain and the UAE.

Oracle already opened its first data centre in the UAE last year in Abu Dhabi and plans to open one more data centre in the UAE, likely in Dubai, and two in Saudi Arabia this year while Microsoft opened its data centres in Dubai and Abu Dhabi last year.

Alibaba Cloud, the cloud computing arm of Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba Group, has already invested in one data centre in the UAE while SAP opened its data centres in UAE and Saudi Arabia last year.

The only big player left is Google.

Big cloud providers need to have local data centres to cater to governments, financial and banking sectors for data residency regulations and that is why big players have opened data centres in the region.

Hossam Seif El-Din, Vice-President for Enterprise and Commercial at IBM Middle East and Africa, told TechRadar Middle East, that IBM has been offering cloud managed services to organisations across various sectors, globally and in the region, through its data centres globally but due to data residency issues, “we found it is important to have local data centres to target banking and government clients for mission-critical applications and data”.

Moreover, he said that only 20% of the companies have moved to the cloud and believe that it is the right time to move to the cloud.

“We see a huge growth opportunity as 80% of the workloads still sit on on-premises.  We not only provide IaaS, PaaS and SaaS but also manage on their behalf.  The data centres will deliver data backup and protection services for customers,” he said.

In the case of a network failure or downtime, he said that data and workloads hosted in the data centres will be recovered instantly and available for use in real-time.

Equinix to open Oman data centre in June next year as digitisation gains traction
Huawei has no intention to be a data centre colocation operator
Oracle sees more UAE governments moving to the cloud platform
Microsoft is witnessing a strong uptake for its data centres in UAE
UAE public cloud market to grow 35% this year

According to an International Data Centre (IDC ) report, the average cost of downtime is $250,000 per hour across all industries and organisational sizes.

 When asked whether IBM is planning to open more data centres in the region, El-Din said: “no comments”.

According to IDC, the public cloud market in the UAE is expected to grow by 35% to $406m in 2020 compared to $299m last year and two-thirds of the organisations will approach the cloud through a hybrid model.

The research firm is seeing a decline in on-premise [non-cloud] spending and a lot of spending is moving to the cloud as a subscription-based model to cut costs.

Manish Ranjan, research firm International Data Corporation’s program manager for software and cloud in the Middle East, Africa, and Turkey, said that looking at the Middle East in isolation, Saudi Arabia and the UAE are the biggest spenders on the public cloud services, with growth rates exceeding the market average.

“There are a lot of opportunities for the cloud in the region and Saudi Arabia is the right place for any cloud provider looking to tap into them. Under the Kingdom's proposed data regulations, vendors that have their own in-country data centres would certainly have the upper hand from a compliance and governance standpoint, particularly when it comes to serving the government, healthcare, and banking sectors,” he said.

For the same reason, he added that local telecom operators are better placed than their international counterparts as they are able to deliver software solutions, infrastructure, and development platforms as a service from in-country data centres.

“As such, local telecom operators across the region are investing heavily in local data centres to meet growing cloud demand,” he said.

Total spending on public cloud services in the Middle East and Africa (MEA) is expected to reach $2.65 billion next year, up from $2.04 billion in 2019.

“Over the longer term, we expect the spending on public cloud services in the region to increase at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 27.2% for the 2018-2023 period,” Ranjan said.

urn:contentItem:5TRD-S741-F11P-X3B2-00000-00IBM opens up its blockchain dev platform to AWS2018-11-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:40ZLexisNexisIBM opens up its blockchain dev platform to AWS

IBM appears hell-bent on establishing its dominance in the fledgling blockchain enterprise market.

The company has announced a bunch of improvements to its IBM Blockchain Platform, which offers a suite of developer tools to build decentralized solutions. Among other things, the platform will now support third-party cloud providers like AWS (Amazon Web Services).

To support clients as they work to accelerate solutions that rely on blockchain, IBM is making the Blockchain Platform something a wide range of clients can implement whether on the IBM Cloud, on another preferred cloud environment such as AWS, or locally using on-premises data centers, the announcement reads.

The news comes days after IBM announced plans to acquire cloud firm Red Hat for $34 billion.

IBM is already seeing a wide range of scenarios and use cases embrace what we are calling the power of anywhere,` wrote IBM VP of blockchain, Jerry Cuomo. Blockchain Platform for AWS is designed to enable clients to deploy distributed peers on the AWS Cloud.

For this occasion, IBM has prepared a deliberately inspirational (and awfully hackneyed) promo video to show off its updated set of blockchain software solutions. It is also offering $500 in credits for anyone interested in trying out a demo.

In addition to expanded support for cloud services, IBM is also rolling out a separate Cloud Private offering specifically designed to ensure compliance with new regulations like GDPR. Unlike its standard offering, Cloud Private promises custom-managed networks with more flexibility and greater control over data.

Big tech invades blockchain

IBM is hardly the only technology giant taking aim at the blockchain market. Recently, Google, Amazon, and Microsoft have all launched similar cloud solutions for blockchain development.

Not so long ago, Cuomo took to the company blog to announce IBM has joined an effort to create decentrlaized cross-blockchain registry that brings permissioned and permissionless blockchains together through a directory of blockchain networks basically a blockchain equivalent of the Yellow Pages.

Indeed, IBM has involved itself in a bevy of decentralized tech projects (like education, food tracking, and Ethereum-powered payments); unfortunately, the company has remained tight-lipped about the technical specifics.

Hopefully, its enterprise blockchain offerings and implementations are better thought out than its application patents.

Correction 18:52 UTC, November 13: This piece wrongly suggested that IBM has completed the acquisition of Red Hat. This is incorrect. A spokesperson has clarified IBM has expressed interest to buy out the cloud service company, but has not yet finalized the detail. Weve updated the piece to reflect this accurately and apologize for the mistake. 2018 Global Data Point.

urn:contentItem:5XFC-5WG1-DYDW-73P0-00000-00IBM powers financial services-specific cloud technology for Bank of America2019-11-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:40ZLexisNexisIBM powers financial services-specific cloud technology for Bank of AmericaNew Delhi, 2019-11-06 15:59:40

November 06 -- International Business Machines (IBM) said that it has built financial services-specific cloud technology for Bank of America.
The public platform, IBM's first industry-specific cloud, is designed to meet the regulatory, security and resiliency standards required of the financial services industry.


"By setting a standard that addresses the concern of hosting highly confidential information, we aim to drive the public cloud to a safety level that is unmatched," said Cathy Bessant, chief operations and technology officer of Bank of America.
Bank of America has focused on its internal cloud computing capabilities. The second largest U.S. bank has reduced its servers to about 70,000 from over 200,000 and cut its data centers to 23 from 67, Reuters reported.
Bank of America has saved $2 billion annually by streamlining those operations, Chief Executive Brian Moynihan said on an earnings call last month. The bank still relies on cloud services from external vendors since third parties can usually offer the service 23-30 percent cheaper, he said.
"We don't need to own the hardware," he said. "We just need to find out who can provide it the right way."
Investing in cloud computing is key for banks as more transactions become digital. It is critical that the platform can transfer information quickly, keep data private, and prevent service outages.
Bank of America customers reported trouble accessing online banking and card services late last month, according to Downdetector.com.
Cloud services used by banks have come under scrutiny in Washington after a massive data breach at Capital One Financial raised questions over the risks posed by banks' reliance on third-party cloud providers.
U.S. lawmakers have asked regulators to consider direct oversight of the cloud services big tech companies provide to banks - like Amazon.comAmazon Web Services, Microsoft's Microsoft Azure and Alphabet's Google Cloud saying they have become a critical component of the global financial system. IBM was not one of the cloud providers mentioned in the letter.

urn:contentItem:7W88-SX01-2R6R-540D-00000-00IBM's $1.2B acquisition of SPSS shows importance of software in IBM transformation2009-07-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:40ZLexisNexisBUSINESSIBM's $1.2B acquisition of SPSS shows importance of software in IBM transformationJORDAN ROBERTSONAP

SAN FRANCISCO _ IBM Corp.(NYSE:IBM) is bulking up its most profitable division with a $1US.2 billion acquisition of business software provider SPSS Inc., a deal that also reflects the power of wealthy technology companies to throw their money around despite the recession.

The all-cash deal announced Tuesday represents a 42 per cent premium over Chicago-based SPSS's closing price of $35.09 on Monday.

SPSS's software helps tell companies ''what's coming around the corner'' and is ''a really terrific acquisition'' for IBM, said Charles King, analyst with the Pund-IT Inc. research firm.

''This is really a Cadillac-style technology ... it's well established and well regarded,'' King said.

SPSS's technology is used to comb through stockpiles of data to predict things such as how a customer will respond to a particular sales pitch, or where hot spots for crime are and where police should be deployed. The company claims its customers include agencies in all U.S. state governments, top U.S. universities and consumer goods, pharmaceutical and market-research companies.

''With this acquisition, we are extending our capabilities around a new level of analytics that not only provides clients with greater insight _ but true foresight,'' Ambuj Goyal, general manager of IBM's Information Management group, said in a statement.

The deal is expected to close later this year, and is subject to shareholder and regulatory approval. SPSS has more than 1,200 employees in 60 countries. The company had $303US million in sales last year and $36 million in profit.

The acquisition fits with IBM's strategy of strengthening its software and services divisions as a critical part of a makeover over the past decade.

IBM has spent more than $20 billion since 2003 on more than 80 acquisitions. Fifty of those acquisitions have been software companies.

One result of the transformation is that IBM, a company known for its mainframes and other computers that have powered back offices for decades, is less reliant now on hardware. Having sold off its personal computer and printing businesses, IBM makes most of its money off services and software.

In the latest quarter _ the three months ended June 30 _ IBM's software division contributed 43 per cent of IBM's overall pretax profit. Expanding its reliance on software is one reason the Armonk, N.Y.-based company is able to keep improving profits even as sales fall because of the economy. IBM recently raised its latest 2009 profit forecast to $9.70 per share, from $9.20 per share.

Separately, IBM also has acquired Ounce Labs Inc., a privately held software company in Waltham, Mass., for an undisclosed amount. IBM said the company makes software that helps businesses reduce the risk and costs associated with security and compliance concerns.

Beefing up the software division was a key reason IBM explored buying Sun Microsystems Inc., a superstar of the dot-com era that struggled with inconsistent financial results for nearly a decade.

The Java technology that Sun invented is a key ingredient of the Internet, and IBM's $7 billion offer for Sun was fuelled in part by a desire to have more control over the software's development. The deal collapsed in a dispute over price and other terms.

Oracle Corp. ultimately agreed to buy Sun for $7.4 billion in cash in a surprise twist in the takeover saga. The bidding was one of the first signs that cash-rich tech companies were willing to open their wallets again despite the recession.

Another big tech deal recently was data-storage specialist EMC Corp.'s $2.1 billion pickup of a company called Data Domain Inc., whose technology helps companies cut the amount of information that gets stored multiple times. EMC had been in a fierce bidding contest with rival NetApp Inc. for control of Data Domain.

SPSS shares on Tuesday jumped $14.27, or 41 per cent, to $49.36. IBM shares fell 73 cents to $116US.90. on the New York Stock Exchange

urn:contentItem:7W87-GGV1-2R2D-1190-00000-00IBM scoops up software maker SPSS in $1.2B deal2009-07-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:40ZLexisNexisBUSINESS NEWSIBM scoops up software maker SPSS in $1.2B dealBy JORDAN ROBERTSONAP Technology WriterSAN FRANCISCO

IBM Corp.is bulking up its most profitable division with a $1.2 billion acquisition of business software provider SPSS Inc., a deal that also reflects the power of wealthy technology companies to throw their money around despite the recession.

The all-cash deal announced Tuesday represents a 42 percent premium over Chicago-based SPSS's closing price of $35.09 on Monday.

SPSS's software helps tell companies "what's coming around the corner" and is "a really terrific acquisition" for IBM, said Charles King, analyst with the Pund-IT Inc. research firm.

"This is really a Cadillac-style technology ... it's well established and well regarded," King said.

SPSS's technology is used to comb through stockpiles of data to predict things such as how a customer will respond to a particular sales pitch, or where hot spots for crime are and where police should be deployed. The company claims its customers include agencies in all U.S. state governments, top U.S. universities and consumer goods, pharmaceutical and market-research companies.

"With this acquisition, we are extending our capabilities around a new level of analytics that not only provides clients with greater insight but true foresight," Ambuj Goyal, general manager of IBM's Information Management group, said in a statement.

The deal is expected to close later this year, and is subject to shareholder and regulatory approval. SPSS has more than 1,200 employees in 60 countries. The company had $303 million in sales last year and $36 million in profit.

The acquisition fits with IBM's strategy of strengthening its software and services divisions as a critical part of a makeover over the past decade.

IBM has spent more than $20 billion since 2003 on more than 80 acquisitions. Fifty of those acquisitions have been software companies.

One result of the transformation is that IBM, a company known for its mainframes and other computers that have powered back offices for decades, is less reliant now on hardware. Having sold off its personal computer and printing businesses, IBM makes most of its money off services and software.

In the latest quarter the three months ended June 30 IBM's software division contributed 43 percent of IBM's overall pretax profit. Expanding its reliance on software is one reason the Armonk, N.Y.-based company is able to keep improving profits even as sales fall because of the economy. IBM recently raised its latest 2009 profit forecast to $9.70 per share, from $9.20 per share.

Separately, IBM also has acquired Ounce Labs Inc., a privately held software company in Waltham, Mass., for an undisclosed amount. IBM said the company makes software that helps businesses reduce the risk and costs associated with security and compliance concerns.

Beefing up the software division was a key reason IBM explored buying Sun Microsystems Inc., a superstar of the dot-com era that struggled with inconsistent financial results for nearly a decade.

The Java technology that Sun invented is a key ingredient of the Internet, and IBM's $7 billion offer for Sun was fueled in part by a desire to have more control over the software's development. The deal collapsed in a dispute over price and other terms.

Oracle Corp. ultimately agreed to buy Sun for $7.4 billion in cash in a surprise twist in the takeover saga. The bidding was one of the first signs that cash-rich tech companies were willing to open their wallets again despite the recession.

Another big tech deal recently was data-storage specialist EMC Corp.'s $2.1 billion pickup of a company called Data Domain Inc., whose technology helps companies cut the amount of information that gets stored multiple times. EMC had been in a fierce bidding contest with rival NetApp Inc. for control of Data Domain.

SPSS shares on Tuesday jumped $14.36, or 41 percent, to $49.45. IBM shares closed 35 cents lower at $117.28.

Expanding its reliance on software is one reason the Armonk, N.Y.-based company is able to keep improving profits even as sales fall because of the economy. IBM recently raised its latest 2009 profit forecast to $9.70 per share, from $9.20 per share.

Separately, IBM also has acquired Ounce Labs Inc., a privately held software company in Waltham, Mass., for an undisclosed amount. IBM said the company makes software that helps businesses reduce the risk and costs associated with security and compliance concerns.

Beefing up the software division was a key reason IBM explored buying Sun Microsystems Inc., a superstar of the dot-com era that struggled with inconsistent financial results for nearly a decade.

The Java technology that Sun invented is a key ingredient of the Internet, and IBM's $7 billion offer for Sun was fueled in part by a desire to have more control over the software's development. The deal collapsed in a dispute over price and other terms.

Oracle Corp. ultimately agreed to buy Sun for $7.4 billion in cash in a surprise twist in the takeover saga. The bidding was one of the first signs that cash-rich tech companies were willing to open their wallets again despite the recession.

Another big tech deal recently was data-storage specialist EMC Corp.'s $2.1 billion pickup of a company called Data Domain Inc., whose technology helps companies cut the amount of information that gets stored multiple times. EMC had been in a fierce bidding contest with rival NetApp Inc. for control of Data Domain.

SPSS shares on Tuesday jumped $14.36, or 41 percent, to $49.45. IBM shares closed 35 cents lower at $117.28.
